column11: Review Text

column8: Awful experience which left me feeling no intimidated and unsafe
column11: My least favourite experience in Sri Lanka so far and the only time I have unfortunately, felt unsafe. The trail itself is very manageable however poorly sign posted, granted we did the sunrise hike so it was dark and misty but even so pretty unclear. When walking we were approached by a local who informed us we were going the wrong way despite the path clearly continuing ahead and insisted we went a different direction. About 15 minutes later we were approached by another local who told us again we had gone the wrong way. Conveniently, the first man that approached us reappeared (he had clearly been following us for the last 15 minutes and had purposely sent us the wrong way). At this point he said that he would show us the way if we paid him. I had read online that this was a common scam on this trail and had also read that they could become very persistent and aggressive if you refused so when we had two men standing next to us in the dark we felt like we had no other option but to pay. We trek regularly and by no means are oppose to paying for a guide when needed but this is not a requirement for this trail and these are not guides but people setting out to deceive and scam. The whole experience is was extremely intimidating which is such a shame as I have felt extremely safe in Sri Lanka up until this point.

Ella Rock is one of Sri Lanka‚Äôs most rewarding hiking experiences, offering breathtaking views and a sense of adventure. The trail passes through tea plantations, eucalyptus forests, and quiet railway tracks, giving hikers a glimpse of local life and natural beauty. Reaching the summit requires moderate effort, but the panoramic views make it worthwhile. On clear days, you can see rolling hills, deep valleys, and even distant waterfalls. Early morning is the best time to hike, as the weather is cooler and the views are clearer. Ella Rock is ideal for nature lovers, photographers, and travelers seeking an active escape in Sri Lanka‚Äôs hill country.

We left the hotel at 4.15pm and walked on the rail tracks until the bottom of the rock. There are a few ways to go up. Just ask a local if you are not sure. Everyone's so helpful. It got dark pretty fast. So, it's better to walk up early part of the day. Take a bottle of water with you. Have to get a ticket right at the top. Not very expensive.

Great adventure and hike, not for the fai hearted, this is a significant challenge as there have been death due to the difficulty. Nevertheless this is a must see. Need to have proper hiking boots, we took a local guide which was over the moon when we gave him LKS5000 (¬£12.50) who only wore a Sorong and flip flops (not sure how he did it) however the day albeit tiering was a great experience not to be missed. The journey started walking along the railway which was a bit unnerving, it soon became apparent that the journey was to make all other Sri Lanka hikes look like babies. The last km being the toughest. There are 2 routes, one which is an easier way but we chose the tough hike, at one point I thought my heart was going to burst out of my chest. Fab day would totally recommend.

column8: Nice hike with a great set of viewpoints.
column11: Moderate walk with a bit of a scramble in places but a great view at the top - take a picnic to eat in the shade up top as there are some nice benches and bathrooms. It was dry and dusty when we did it but some parts are over bare rock and would be awful wet. Wear good trainers/hiking shoes - this isn‚Äôt one for flip flops. Take at least a litre of water each, personally I‚Äôd suggest two especially if climbing any time after 9am. There is a small ticket charge to get into the summit area with the viewpoints, presumably as it has been tidied up with the benches etc. (970rp as of Sept 2025 - the ticket box had plenty of change). As others have said - the locals are deliberately concealing the start of the trail/destroying the markers and will also deliberately misdirect you to extort money. The photo I‚Äôve included is what is currently blocking the start of the trail as you cross the footbridge after coming along the tracks from Kithalella (the branches) - go past these a little and bear to the left through the tea plantation (the trail as marked on Google maps is actually pretty accurate), don‚Äôt pass the house as you‚Äôll be directed further into the forest the wrong way. Hopes this saves someone else the misdirection from the locals! There are a couple of locals selling coconuts/cold drinks at fair prices on the marked part of the trail - handy on the way down!

column8: Great sunrise hike - be prepared for aggressive tip seekers
column11: We departed at night to catch the sunrise, and we successfully did so. However, we did encounter one of those locals that initially points the way and then follows at a distance to aggressively take over at the first uncertain fork in the unmarked trail. We actually let him do this because it saved us time enough to make it up before sunrise, even though we had a downloaded map. If you don't like this, and I imagine most would not, and you have a downloaded map, be sure to politely say right away you already know the way and make it clear you won't be tipping.  On your own expect to stop at a lot of unmarked forks to determine the right one because the tea fields naturally have a lot of worker paths and in the dark it's hard to see where they all go, but it isn't that hard. You will also go right by front doors of homes and near other buildings so don't think you made a mistake just because of that. Sometimes the correct fork in the road is the narrow path through the weeds.

Fantastic, stunning route. Ignore painted arrow ‚ÄòElla rock‚Äô on rail track by the shrine. Locals use this short cut via someone‚Äôs house to con you with ‚Äòguide‚Äô fees once they latch on to you.

column8: Climbing Ella Rock with Sadish ‚Äì fantastic local guide
column11: We had a great experience climbing Ella rock with Sadish +94741048652 He is a very kind and knowledgeable guide. Super punctual early morning, easy to communicate in English, and he knows the whole area by heart, as he is from the area. The way up we took the quick (and steep) way. It starts off at Kitha Ella train station (as usual) but then take a straight route to the top (just 2 km). At certain points is a bit demanding but overall very doable (my wife and I did it without problems (nearing 50s‚Äô) and our son, 12 yo, climbed playing with the dogs around. Then we asked him to take the larger route to descend, a more gentle walk. In the way down, he explained us the many different trees that can be found and had a lovely conversation about the area. He charged us 7000 rupees for the excursion including pick up and return to our hotel with his tuktuk. The route is extremely beautiful, and we had an amazing time!

It is a great shame that such a beautiful city with so many interesting places is so dirty and envied by plastic waste and the competent bodies do not take strong initiatives to prevent its use and, above all, clean the entire area.

I started the solo tour from Ella's train tracks. The truth is that it is a pleasant walk with spectacular views (beware of the train when it passes!!!). At the end of the train tracks, I started trekking through some nice rice paddies and started ascending the mountain. Clarify that once you pass the rice paddies area becomes a trekking of medium/high difficulty. The indications were not clear (I saw several people get lost, including me) because there were severed and poorly indicated accesses. When I reached the top, I found a hut in which to enjoy mountain views you had to pay 930 rupees... I found it outrageous to have to pay for being on a mountain.

Very nice walk, first over and next to the railway then through tea fields, rice fields, and then through forest and bush up the mountain. A little adventurous and some help through the (free version of) alltrails.com app. There were also stretches of nice and spicy mountain, but enough rest points to catch your breath. The tourist who only goes 500m on concrete lanes to the attraction, will suffer here. The trained hikers will find the number of tourists on the trail annoying. You're not alone, but it's certainly not a flight of stairs up. For our family a very varied walk, especially if you make a loop trail where the second part of the loop is off the beaten track. Oh yes, a minus... when you are almost at the top of the viewpoint you have to pass another "nature reserve" checkpoint. 800lrs per person.

Before you start your hike up to Ella Rock, you should download one of the offline map apps like maps.me or mappy.cz and follow the paths indicated there. We have been told that false signs have been placed on the trail to mislead hikers, leaving them to rely on local ‚Äúguides‚Äù to lead them back to the correct path. We found the hike to be quite forward and simple using maps.me and in our opinion you don‚Äôt need any signs nor guides. However, we ourselves did not have the experience that they wanted to lure us to a wrong path.
Having to pay 950 rps per person just before the point of view is clearly abused!!! Have a phone with the plot because nothing is displayed and sometimes you wonder where you are.

Ella Rock is a must-do for nature and hiking lovers! The trail is a bit challenging but totally worth it for the stunning views at the top. üåøüåû We started early to avoid the heat and crowds‚Äîgreat idea! There are no signs, so it‚Äôs good to ask locals or go with a guide. üß≠ Bring water and good shoes. The sunrise view was unforgettable. Peaceful, scenic, and a real adventure in Ella

Compared to other vistas of Sri Lanka, this is my top. Viewpoint views aren't exactly wow, but decent. Here's the case where the road to the summit is steeper than the views from the summit. Every few tens of meters, the picture changes. First cross the river, then the tea plantations, then different areas of the forest, the open path again. There are wet areas where you need to climb rocks and walk on water, it is more careful, it can be slippery and muddy. Closer to the summit there are seats, food is sold water and snacks to eat, at the top the entrance ticket - oops 930 rupees, you can buy water.

The route at the start is not well-marked, locals will try to charge you to guide you, after the first third of the climb it opens up onto a path that is easy to follow, the path is a rough path, not steps, quite uneven and rocky but taking your time and good walking shoes helps, there were a few stalls selling water and drinks on the way up but best to take your own water. It took me about 45 minutes to get to the top, but I am very fit, an hour is more usual. When you get to the top, there is a fence about 30 mtrs from the viewpoint and a sign asking for LKR 930 to enter, I told the man he could dream on if he thought I was paying that for the last 30 mtrs, and he said OK. Go in then. The day I went up it was quite misty, so not the best view. There are free toilets at the top if needed. It did start raining as I started down, and it made some of the paths quite slippery. It is easier to find your way back down as long as you made a mental note of the route on the way up. A much more challenging and enjoyable climb than Little Adams peak, far less crowded as long as you are reasonably fit.
Very nice hike. We were accompanied by a farmer who took care of us. Even if we had to give a little ticket the hike would not have been so nice without him.

Our favourite thing we did during our time in Ella.  If you are reasonably fit and have some decent walking shoes it‚Äôs not too difficult with a round trip taking just over 3 hours.  It was lovely to get away from the crowds of Little Adam‚Äôs Peak and the Nine Arch Bridge and be able to enjoy the amazing scenery Sri Lanka has to offer. A few tips: +Read a couple of online blogs from people who have done the walk so you get an idea of the route. Many will include some pictures so you now where to look out for the path.  It‚Äôs not overly difficult and you‚Äôll likely see others doing the same walk. +Be wary of any locals pointing you onto the path. +The path is rocky and can be slippy/muddy in places depending on the weather so some good shoes are needed. +Check the weather - you want to be able to see the view and not be stuck in cloud at the top.
Very beautiful and worth a  trip. Takes about 3 hours to walk. Bring camera and water and you'll have a great and beautiful experience.

I loved this little hike. I paid for a guide from my HomeStay because I didn‚Äôt feel comfortable finding my way alone in the dark, I am glad I did as it seemed even my guide was double checking the route. It can be a challenge so appropriate footwear is recommended for this trail. The sunrise was beautiful. You need to pay for entry to the viewpoint.

Stunning views at the top. We just missed the sunrise but still beautiful with the low morning sun. Definitely recommend to do in the morning. We highly recommend to get a guide as the root is very complicated and not sign posted. You need to be quite fit to do this. You need trainers or trekking shoes.

An excellent walk with an amazing view at the top (you have to pay 930 LKR per person to get to the viewpoint) but BEWARE of locals, who will try to take you off the path - whatever they say don‚Äôt listen! We had one man come up to us wearing a uniform claim the path was covered in leeches (with the bloody feet to ‚Äúprove it‚Äù) and we should go a different route - we did and inevitably another local came to guide us to the top and expected a cash payment afterwards. When we came back down the route we originally planned there was not a leech in sight!

A nice little mountain tour from Ella. Along the railroad tracks. Then through a tea plantation and through varied mountain forest to the viewpoint Ella Rock. 1,350 meters high. So far so beautiful. Unfortunately, in the area of the railway line, shady boys are on the way who pose as faint guids and deliberately mislead you to pick up tourists. You can't rely on the signage. We were forewarned but three attempts were made to send us wrong. So stay on your way (map, nav app) and clearly say no no no. Gutes Gelingen üëç

Ella Rock, a must-do hike in Ella, Sri Lanka! The trail, though challenging at times, rewards with breathtaking panoramic views of lush valleys, tea plantations, and the charming town below. The journey takes you through diverse landscapes, from serene tea gardens to dense forests. While the hike can be demanding, the sense of accomplishment and the stunning vistas at the summit make it an unforgettable experience. Remember to wear sturdy footwear, carry ample water, and be prepared for varying weather conditions.

Just be mindful that the beginning passes along the actual railway, so you'll need to pay attention to the train!  Gorgeous scenery, waterfalls, and lush greenery During the rainy season, it's best to go early because it tends to rain often starting around noon.
*It is a very amazing place.üò±üò± *One of the best places I've seen üåè *A place with accommodation facilities for tourists.

My Family recently visited the place where you can VIEW the Ella Rock.  The visit itself was spectacular and will be a memorable family moment for years to come. Here are some travel tips that may help you: (1) The view of the Ella Rock is best seeing from the spot where the Flying Ravana (Zipline/Swing & Little Adams Peak) are located. This is all in the same location at the top of the same steep hill. Autos are able to take you to the top where you can explore all three attractions. The walk to the top is not a short one and quite steep. There are little stalls/shops selling water and snacks along this hill. The drive is bumpy but it's a lovely view of the Ella Rock and the high elevation/and green landscape. * The view of the Ella rock at the top is spectacular (as you can see from my photos). If you choose to climb Little Adam's Peak, make it a separate trip and go early in the morning (for the sunrise, or around that time) as the afternoon sun can be quite hot. * Both my children did the Swing at the top, by the Ravana Pool Club (noted in (1) and it was fabulous experience for them (and for us watching them). We did not rent the dresses as my daughter took her own. This is a must do if you enjoy heights and want to get some memorable photos of the incredible view of the Ella Rock. Take an Umbrella in case it‚Äôs very sunny so that you can shield yourself from the heat. The Ravana Pool Club is beautiful if you want to get a drink or a bite to eat. Costs are $$$ on the scale. The use of the Ravana Pool Club swimming pool is based on a package deal which you can buy at the entrance of the club, at the top of this hill (Cost is $$$$) (2) The Nine Arches bridge is in a separate location not too far from the Flying Ravana/Swing area. The Auto's are able to take u right to the top where you can walk to the bridge in a few minutes. * If you get Auto's offering you 'package deals' to visit the (1) & (2) above - it should not cost more than Rs. 8,000 for two people to visit both locations. (Unfortunately, because we didn't know the distance between the locations, we ended up paying more than double this price for 4 adults. Lesson learned for next time :) Other Tips for your stay in Ella: * Booking a hotel in Ella Town makes it very convenient to travel to the Ella Rock, and other attractions and restaurants. * The commute from our hotel in Ella Town to the Ella Rock (which is viewable from the Ravana Pool Club / Flying Ravan) was about 10-15 mins (or less from our Hotel). My suggestion is: if you have a driver who can take u to the base of the Ravana Pool Club/Flying Ravana, you can get an auto at the base of the road and only pay about Rs 1,000 - Rs. 1,200 which will drive you to the Top of the hill to view the Rock/Visit Ravana Pool Club/experience the Flying Ravana zip line /Swing (All in the exact same location beside each other). * While there are no 'mosquitoes or bugs flying around visibly', the area is rich in biodiversity, dense with numerous varieties of flora and fauna - which could cause bug bites (especially if you are new to the country/and travelling with children). Make sure to take some After bit cream and to dress comfortably. Any other question - don‚Äôt hesitate to reach out and enjoy your trip :)

Beautiful vistas, a nice relatively challenging hike. I echo what the others warn about scammers. While I didn‚Äôt  face these scammers, I heard directly from hikers that experienced it - notably being taken on dubious routes only to be asked for money to be taken on the correct path. The route is pretty easy to follow via markings and Google maps, once you leave the railway tracks and cross the bridge. One other thing to note is that there is a 930 LKR entrance fee. Make sure the ticket guy actually issues you with a ticket once you paid. When I was the there the ticket guy was reluctant to issue a ticket (possibly because he‚Äôs pocketing the money himself ;))

Guiding visitors through Ella is always a delightful experience, as this picturesque town in Sri Lanka‚Äôs Hill Country offers a perfect blend of natural beauty and serene charm. From the moment you arrive in Ella, you‚Äôre greeted by a landscape of lush green hills, cascading waterfalls, and breathtaking views that make it a standout destination. One of the most rewarding aspects of guiding in Ella is showcasing its stunning viewpoints. The famous Ella Rock and Little Adam‚Äôs Peak offer panoramic vistas that are truly awe-inspiring. The trek to these viewpoints, surrounded by verdant tea plantations and misty valleys, is a memorable adventure that allows visitors to connect with the natural beauty of Sri Lanka‚Äôs highlands. Another highlight of Ella is the magnificent Nine Arches Bridge, an architectural marvel that stands amidst a lush, verdant backdrop. The sight of the old bridge arching gracefully over the greenery, especially when a train crosses it, creates a magical and quintessentially Sri Lankan experience. The serene atmosphere of Ella also extends to its waterfalls, such as Ravana Falls and Diyaluma Falls. These cascading beauties offer a refreshing escape and provide excellent opportunities for photography and relaxation. Witnessing visitors‚Äô awe as they experience the cool spray and majestic views is always a joy. Ella‚Äôs vibrant local culture and friendly community add to the charm of the town. Exploring the local markets, tasting traditional Sri Lankan cuisine, and engaging with the locals provide visitors with a deeper understanding of the region‚Äôs cultural heritage. For anyone looking to experience the natural splendor and relaxed ambiance of Sri Lanka‚Äôs highlands, Ella is a must-visit destination. Its breathtaking landscapes, captivating viewpoints, and welcoming atmosphere make it a truly enchanting place to explore. Join us in Ella and discover the beauty and serenity that make this highland town so special.

A beautiful walk with stunning views.  The walk is definitely worth doing but do not listen to the locals at the shrine- continue on the railway line til the station.  The locals scammed us.  They deliberately sent us on a wild goose chase 50 meters before the train station- from where the route would have been very obvious.  The lady tried to get us lost and was very rude to another tourist who joined us very frightened by this group. She then said we owed her 60 dollars!! Do the walk but be prepared üòÄ

We left from Ella and followed the route along the railway. But we were misled by a lady pointing us out the route. About 20 minutes later we were ‚Äòrescued‚Äô from the bush by a gentle farmer who was ‚Äòso kind‚Äô joining us on our walk. We ‚Äòaccidentally ‚Äò passed by some guys who had drinks to offer. Once at the top (I have to say it was quite a challenge, sometimes quite steep), we were requested to pay 1000 roepies per person for entrance. Some people refused, some not. I checked on some sites where it was mentioned, so I paid. Once back in Ella our guide said we should not have paid, he said locals abuse tourists. But anyhow; the views are amazing, don‚Äôt get scared by this review; for me it‚Äôs a must do!!

Sad to say we were scammed by farming locals here as we tried to enjoy the half day hike to Ella Rock. Signs have been either tampered with  or made up as part of a fairly devious network of locals which fooled nearly all the tourists we met. Do not accept any help or direction from locals. We were seemingly helpfully pointed down a track by locals and the ruse was then taken over by a local lady who continued to send us the wrong way then "rescued" us, "guided" us and then stopped on the track and demanded money. Nearly everyone we met (15 to 20 singles, couples, groups) had experienced the same by a scarily large network of local people. The rip offs ranged from. 500 to 5000 Lkr and made for an uneasy, unpleasant day.  Be sure of your route,  use GPS or a testable trail app and do not trust the signage or locals. Apart from the scam it's a great half day hike. You have to pay 950 rs cash only for the last 50 ms to see the view. The reality of travel.

Great walk and fantastic view. Beware of "friendly locals" who scam you. See my pictures - don't get tricked into taking the path that has a fake arrow and sign on the rail tracks, just over the rail bridge and beside a small shrine (it does go to a waterfall) - that path has a few diverging paths which the "friendly locals" then rescue you from being lost then expect you to pay for the privilege. Instead, stay on the rail tracks for about 5 mins of walking past the little train station. Then stay on the main path. You will come to a fork where there is a sign advising how much it costs at the top (viewing location), stay left at that sign, then follow the path from there.

Incredible views and lovely hike. If you are anyway fit from doing gym or spin classes, you will find this walk easy. Steep incline for the last 20 mins but otherwise fairly easy. Other reviews are accurate, so watch out for people telling you to go on longer routed, so use Google maps. If going from Kitha Station drop off point, walk about 300 yards, past a little cafe and take a left, left again where the river is on your right. Walk down and turn right over the bridge and it splits into straight ahead or to the left a quick steep incline. Take the left, it's a shorter more direct route and no chance of leeches. This left turning is after the bridge almost look like you are going up in between a hedge and walk straight and follow Google maps.

A sunrise hike to Ella Rock is well worth the visit. We were unsure if it was worth getting a tour guide at first - but I‚Äôm so glad we did, I don‚Äôt think I would have felt comfortable hiking in the dark without one and it meant that we stayed on the right track and made it to the top for the sunrise. Our guide was organised by our hotel. We started the hike at the railway track and made it to the top in about an hour and a half. The climb itself is manageable but suitably challenging, although we might have felt that more because we were pushing ourselves to get to the top in time! At the top you have to pay a small environmental fee and there are toilets nearby. When you see the sun rise it is so worth it, you are surrounded by mountains and the view is breathtaking. We were pleasantly surprised there were only about 6 other people at the top so we could really enjoy the tranquility of it all. The walk back down stunning, through beautiful trees and tea plantations. If I ever visited Ella again I wouldn‚Äôt think twice about doing this again. Loved it.
Climbing ella rock was a majical experiance I used travel monkey as my guide stayed at the flower garden hotel - great place

I got a rad guide from the Ella New Green View, older dude named Kumara. I can definitely get the appeal of doing a hike on your own, but I‚Äôm glad I didn‚Äôt. We helped more than a couple lost travelers hunched over their phones in the jungle at four thirty AM, my man Kumara actually leading a small troupe at one point. The sunset is amazing, and you will have to pay a ticket, about 1000 LKR as of the time of his review. Get a guide, do the hike, definitely worth it.

Pleasant hike, We came across a person pointing us the wrong way (we read on blogs to be careful that this happens). You also had to pay the last 50 meters to enjoy the view. Too bad to monetize this. If I had known I would not have paid.
It was great. Trees were amazing. Also there are two view points. I loved the second one because not many people know about it.
A beautiful place with views. We didn‚Äôt climb the mountain, we walked around the area with a guide. Downstairs is Hotel 98, where you can eat after your walk

We start from near the Kitha Ella station, walk along the tracks and then at a certain point turn right (you will find local people at this junction). The climb to the panoramic point takes about an hour. I entrusted myself to a local person who, for a few euros, accompanied me along secondary roads both outward and return. Unfortunately, once we got to the top everything was completely covered and I wasn't able to see the view from the two viewpoints. Once you get to the top the entrance to the panoramic points costs 900 rupees (honest in not making me pay for the entrance since the visibility was zero)

Beware of scams. Locals will mislead you on purpose and then later force you to have a tour. Don‚Äôt trust the ‚Äúfarmers‚Äù or people on the train tracks, they all work together. Walk until the train station - then take the path up there. It‚Äôs a pity because the landscape is nice. Don‚Äôt recommend going there in the first place. I‚Äôm sure a less popular hike is just as nice.

Incredible views and walk, one of the best things I have done in Sri Lanka, would recommend as not only is the viewpoint incredible but the walk itself is insane walking along the railtrack, through vegetable and tea fields, jungle areas and forest, took 4 hours with rests and pictures, the effort is worth it! (i walk a decent amount but for non regular walkers would still recommend, plenty of places to stop along the way if willing to give the time!) :)

Great walk, follow the path to the top for a wonderful view. Locals may offer to help you find the route if you get lost, but will ask for some money after. Make sure you see both view points. Beware of leeches If raining wear long trousers if needed.

Ella Rocks Facility has been Revived after the Economic Downturns, Covid Pandemic & other undesirable events. Exceptional Happening place with Positive Vibes & Frequency.  'Hands On' exercise is immeasurably Useful aligning well with Elegant Facilitation & Guidance for Nature,  Natural Surroundings, Health, Meat Alternatives & the modern concept of 'Going Back to Nature' Highly Recommended  ! Go for it ! Have Fun !

Easy one hour walk from the station. After half a kilometer take a path to the left. You will realize that it is the correct one because you will cross a small bridge. Immediately after, turn left and you will arrive at your destination without problems. Nothing much to see, especially because charging (even more than the locals) makes it all a bit annoying.

We hiked up the quiet back trails from the railway and ended up in front of a big sign indicating that we have to pay an entrance fee to get to the viewpoints. Which the views are night but: Wow‚Ä¶ again foreigners pay way more than locals. Cannot say if it‚Äôs worth. We talked with the guards what the money is used for and they said for example tending to the forest. Later we passed two dead trees that for safety reasons should better be cut dow. In retrospect I would say it‚Äôs better to go up Little Adams peak as long as this one‚Äôs still free.
Road worth it just for the last 30 minutes, 900 Rupees to see the view, if I went back I wouldn't do it again, there are a million better things to do in Sri Lanka

The place has fantastic views, but after walking for about 3 hours, getting lost along the way on several occasions... We managed to reach the top and were surprised to have to pay 900 rupees per person. We got there following the instructions of a traveler's blog and even so, several of the signs that indicated them had been removed from the train tracks. Therefore, you take an unmarked route, without receiving help or any type of service (just some bathrooms without water) and in exchange, you have to pay 900 rupees to be able to enjoy the views after 3 hours of climbing. We recommend the maps app. me to find the way

This is a great experience but you probably need a local or guide unless you are very good at finding your own way. Fabulous views, but quite an energetic walk. Much tougher than I expected, so you need full mobility. Having said that, definitely one of the best things to do in Ella. Don‚Äôt miss the hidden temple at the top!

Ella Rock is nice hier with nice view. Be careful however about wrong guides!! When arriving at the trailhead. Some local, young man showed us a direction which was "a much shorter one". Several times he pointed us to the wrong direction and "rescued" us shortly after. He was very nice and told us about his family etc. When he started saying that the other way is more dangerous (Cobras and wasps), I remembered that I had seen a travel blog about this. They only want your money at the end, having guided you to the view points. We gave him some LKR at half the way and managed to find the view point without him.
Beautiful view from the top. But since a few days, you have to pay an entrance fee at the top. For foreigners adults: 900LKR children: 450LRK. It is a little much for just a beautiful view.

ROUTE INFO! We started at kithalella train station - from behind get onto the tracks and go left. Keep walking along the tracks until you see on the right a green house with brown/ red tin roof set down the bank. Go past that and left (you will walk through what feels like their garden but the people are friendly) Over the bridge (the one with a waterfall huge drop on the left) then immediate right and first left through tall grass. From here the route is easier to follow and a couple of options will lead you to the same place at the top. Stray dogs actually led us! Very friendly and don‚Äôt bark at all. Couple of guys selling fruit and drinks on the way up if you wanted to support them. 3 view points, one is early on and finally the trees drop away to a valley on the left. Very nice but keep going through the trees to a log cabin and camping area where you find view 2. From here keep going past another house, A frame style and you eventually come to a tiny view point in the grass where the path stops. This is nice but worth the extra walk maybe not. It took us 2hr 30 in total including plenty of photos stops and we sat for 20-30 mins at the to to eat. This is a detailed route guide as previous reviews warned locals try to misdirect you, which I did experience. I took 1 hour 15 up and 50 mins down, but going fast as I wanted to catch the 09.20 bus to Matara (via shower and breakfast). At a steady pace and with pauses to enjoy the views, allow 3 to 3 1/2 hours. 1. Join train track either at Ella station or along Waterfall Rd where they run alongside each other. 2. Stay on train track for 30 (fast)-40 mins, walk over bridge. 3. Continue 3-5 mins, to Kital Ella station, and then a further 6-8 mins. 4. Take the little path on the left - a sharp left, almost back on yourself. You know it‚Äôs the right path if in literally 1 minute you‚Äôre on a small footbridge over a fast-flowing river. 5. Continue on path past tea plantations. In 5-7 mins you will see the first ‚ÄòElla Rock‚Äô signpost. 6. Now you go mostly up through forest. Depending on your pace you will reach a nice viewpoint in 10-20 mins, and the summit in a further 15-25 mins. There is a wooden hut and (I assume usually) a fruit juice stall, and super views (unless the cloud is low!) 7. Return the way you came**. **I heard there is another viewpoint 10 minutes further on. Perhaps someone could confirm this in a future review?

when hiking up from the small village of Ella up to the Ella Rock mountain peak, I made new local friends (from the cities of Sri Lanka). together, we had a great time strolling through the thick, green forest and then enjoying the view over the valley below the peak. one of many must-see places in Sri Lanka!

It's a bit difficult to reach because of the steep slope and because you'll find people who will try to trick you in order for ypu tp get lost. However, if you know how to get there (maps or other people's blogs), go for it! The views on the top are spectacular!

Nice walk to one of the highest points in the areas. First part is over the train rails. Be sure to take the right road /direction after leaving the rails. The last past is the most difficult but still easy to go up under the trees.

This place is perfect for trip for 2 hours from parking. For trip is ideal some good shoes and take water, because the way up is for 45 minutes to sharp hill. On the top you can buy some snack and coconut. The only bad think on our trip to Ella‚Äôs Rock were fake guides on the start of way, who wants show you way up and when you (as always) say ‚Äúno, we dont want guide‚Äù every 10 meters, they continue with you up and then they want 1500 ruppies...

You do not need a guide to climb it; there are plenty of blogs on the internet with good indications. However you should leave early in the morning before the heat! Also, later in the day, the views are not so nice beacuse it gets too misty. The hike itself is a more challenging compared to Little Adams Peak but still completely doable since you mostly hike in the shade of trees.

Ella is famous because of the breathtaking view at top off little adam's peak, Its a small hike around 30,40min. Cold weather and you will enjoy teh nice view from the beginning to  end. You should do this if you travel via Ella.
Ella is  so famous because of the amazing view. Its so beautiful. This trekking is so fun and amazing. Luckily it was not raining but weather is cold. You must visit this place.

I was very happy I didn't get up early in the morning to see the sunrise. We left at 6am and was up and down within 2 hours and half. The views are nice, but I couldnt help thinking it was pretty much the same views as little adams peak with half the effort. If you are stuck for time in ella, I would definitely recommend skipping this and just doing little adams peak.

I hated myself on the way up but the view is so worth it the other view 10 min away is even better don‚Äôt listen to the people (locals) they try to take u a wrong way try to find a map and stick to it
That is a amazing mountain range is sri lanka its called ella gap with very beautiful plantations and also lovely views.

Finding Ella rock is easy, yet some blogs make it seem hard and confusing. 1- Follow the train tracks to Kithalella station 2- Continue to follow the tracks another 5mins keeping an eye on your left for a hairpin turn. (Photo below) 3- Follow the path past tea plantations, cross a bridge and BOOM there is an Ella track sign up to your left. (Photo attached) 4- Follow this track on the left up past more tea plantations and past a coconut stand. 5- Up, up, Up. Along a ridge, through some gum trees. You really can‚Äôt go wrong, the track is well worn and most ways lead up from there. To backup just a bit, one local pointed us in the ‚Äúwrong direction‚Äù, but really there are two ways up and I just believe he was sending us up the harder way. No thanks :) For that, 3 other locals pointed us in the right direction anyways! People are just happy to see tourists atm, so enjoy these epic summits to yourself and give a little back by buying a coconut, it‚Äôs all good! 2.5hrs round trip from Ella st.

We went on Ella Rock in the afternoon. It's not easy to find  the right path but other people who went down told us how to get there. The views from the summit are amazing! Huge space and endless gerrnery. We also had a great company - two cute dogs which led us on the top. Unfortunately when we got the top the weather started to go bad and we had to hurry up to go down.

We went for a sunrise hike with a local guide. It definitely worth to get a guide as routes are not easy to find in the dark. Unfortunately there was no sunrise that morning but the views were great, we could see so far away. It took us a bit more than an hour to get to the top from the train station. The last section was a bit strenuous but manageable. I didn't mind at all for waking up early as the weather is pleasant during dawn. We started after 4am and were back 8am for breakfast. I would really recommend the hike.

My wife and I enjoyed the climb of Ella Rock. It required a little searching but not too complicated. There were plenty of people coming down to guide us with a magnificent view as reward for reaching the top. When returning via the eucalyptus forrest we passed by the Farma Cafe, run by a very kind local, mr Mahijood (Jodi). The cafe is on the way up just after the bridge, taking the path on the right. Turns out that Jodi is a splendid host, who speaks 8 languages and was very entertaining. He is also a great cook! We decided to participate in a cooking classes which Jodi provided in the Farma Cafe the next day. He shared the recipes with us and gave a full demonstration how to prepare the food! Delicious and a great experience! Unique to witness how you can create truly flavoured curries with fresh ingredients from his own garden. Either simply pass by the Farma cafe or you can reach him at +94 786985848 to schedule a training. Enjoy it!

We went left from the train station and followed instructions from a blog (and a nice local man when we got lost!) and found the hike pretty easy. It took about 6 hours but didn‚Äôt feel that long - the views were lovely and varied and the walk wasn‚Äôt too hard bar the final few minutes of the ascent. The views from the summit are amazing!

Great trekking with stunning views across the hills. It takes 4h go and return (8km) from Ella railway station and can be easily done without a guide if you check some websites that show you the way up (with pictures). The path goes along the raildroad track, tea fields and the woods along the hill.

20 mins distance away from Ella city Center,we had to do hiking nearly 2 hrs to reach the place,early morning with birds singing we did hike to the rock,really amazing place,worth to visit the place after long long walk,feel relaxed and happy after reaching the place,vanished our tired even,love to see this place,

Despite reading all the blogs with instructions on how to get there we still took a wrong turn and went the long way. Leave first thing in the morning to avoid heat of the day sun burning you to a crisp. Half the journey involves walking along the train tracks which is fun and a good photo opportunity. You'd have to be pretty stupid to miss the massive trains that occasionally go by but do keep your wits about you, especially if crossing the bridge bit. Also watch out for malevolent locals who try and tell you the wrong way to go so you end up paying for a guide. From what we could see, once you leave the train tracks, cross the river and hit the tea plantations, there are two routes to take. One leads straight up the ridge first through the tea fields (this is the main route everyone should take). The other (which we took) loops round to the right and involves a climb up a steep hill following red arrows with not another soul in sight bar some local cafe owner telling you you're going the right way. I'm pretty sure he made that route so you go past his shop. Confusingly signs point you in both directions but either way, eventually you make it to the viewing point and then there's a steep 30 min climb to the top. At the top, wait your turn for a photo and then head back down for lunch in town. If you wanted you could also dip your blistered feet in the river shown in the photo.

We walked along the railway from Ella and after Kitha Ella station and took the second left turn into the tea plantations after the station. We walked past the correct turn the first time and had to turn back. There are very few signs. You don‚Äôt need a guide though, just plan your route. It took about 2 hours to get to the top and that included getting lost for a bit. It was quite a steep climb for the last 20 minutes or so but so worth it. Views are spectacular from the top. There are people selling welcome cool fresh coconuts and fruit at the top too. This is a must do free activity in Ella.

The whole experience was incredibly amazing and I would totally do it again in a heart beat. It took 3hours 45mins to complete the walk both up and down but it may take longer if you are a slow walker or have younger children

Go early to beat the crowd but whenever, you will be rewarded with a beautiful view. You pass through tea plantation and some lemon grass land before a  midway stop lookout point where some people will end their trip as the last bit is a bit more steep, but really doable, don‚Äôt get discouraged! Worth to stop at the top of a little waterfall on your way back and even cool your feet off.

The hike was challenging as it is hot and walking uphill for one hour is tough... but the views along the way (there is a viewpoint half way) and from the top made it worth it. Definitely recommend to start the hike as early as possible. No guide needed once you found the correct path from the railroad.

We didn‚Äôt have a guide, but our driver hiked with us and helped us find our way. I recommend getting a guide (around 1,500 rupees) as the trail isn‚Äôt well marked and the signs used are often contradictory. It‚Äôs quite steep the whole time, but you‚Äôre on the shade with a nice breeze. We didn‚Äôt wake up early enough for sunrise, but instead got to the top around 7am.
A rather confusing and difficult climb but well worth it. the Nomadic boys advice on how to climb was the best. Well done guys.

All reviews and blog posts we‚Äôve read (bar one) say that the hike to Ella Rock starts with a 1/2 hour trek from Ella along the railway tracks. Since we were in a hurry, we decided to take the less-travelled route by grabbing a tuktuk to Kithalella station (600 rupees for us each way) which saved us about 1 hour across both legs. The hike up itself took us about 75-80 minutes, and another 60 to get down. For the route itself, there are plenty of resources on the web to help you figure your way up. It‚Äôs best to have a read on these before proceeding if you go guideless (entirely possible). The general principle is to make your way to the top of the ridge line (sometimes called a tree line in the reviews) as quickly as possible, then to follow along it until the steep part of Ella Rock where the real ascent begins. Walking on the side of the ridge (which we tried on the way down) was less pleasant and had no views to boast of. All the best!

A lot of steps (7,000 my cell says) all together but worth the climb for the aerobics and for the incredible view at the top.  Several interesting things to see during the climb including the Lions Entrance about half way up the mountain.  Be careful of sand on some of the stairs which make them slippery.

My family with four daughters all managed this beautiful walk yesterday. It was very hot so comfortable clothes are a must and the earlier you can start the better (less heat, more visibility). The walk is stunning, taking in the train track, tea plantations and plenty of stops to get refreshments. The walk does get quite steep towards the top so you definitely need suitable footwear (no flip flops) but it‚Äôs definitely worth it for the view at the top where you can get a coconut or juice from a vendor. Beautiful
My friends and I took our time walking to and climbing Ella Rock. There were two paths - we took the steep one (left) up and the flatter one (right) down.

We did this hike starting at 700 am and it Was perfect. You can do for sunrise but we didn‚Äôt. The longer you wait in the day it will be harder. We used a guide and it was worth the 2500 because many paths can mislead you. The hike took us 3 hours and 30 min with a stop at the top for fresh juice. Well worth the long hike!!

Amazing views of the surrounding valleys and mountains.  Nice shade trees for walking up the steep part which was great as we did the walk in the middle of the day.  It took us about four hours from Ella including a picnic at the top and swim just before looping back onto the railway.

I was too tired with all the sightseeing happening thought if i would be able to make it,finally i decided to give it a try. If i could make it at Tigers Nest in Bhutan sure i could do this. Thanks too all the reviews that encouraged and helped me to finally make it. Spectacular view,worth it.

We took 3 hours for a round trip from the centre of Ella and back and covered about 10km in all. We left at around 8.30am to try to escape the heat (we didn't!) and soon realised that trying to escape day time heat in Sri Lanka was virtually impossible. We didn't use a guide and found our way based on photographs that were shown to us by our friendly waiter at the Ella Heritage hotel where we went for breakfast even though we were staying somewhere else. (Would consider staying here next time as it's set on a quiet road and in a beautiful English-looking cottage). I already had some idea of the route based on what I found on the net, but found those photographs were way more useful since we saw no blue arrows or benches that were mentioned online. A local lady even "helpfully" pointed us in the WRONG direction. The first 3km is a very easy walk on the railway track and you have to pass the Kithaella train station and walk for a further stretch before there is a path on the left by a mango tree which you want to take. There is a shack selling drinks and snacks (cheapest coconut drink for only 80 LKR on the whole route). From there you will cross a bridge, and unlike some blogs that direct you to the right of the bridge, you take a left past a termite hill and from there just keep moving, taking a right when you come to a fork. As you move further along you will come to a cafe (coconut drinks for an exorbitant 150LKR here!). Continue moving past it and from here things start becoming steeper and you will see lovely views from the ridge with the forest behind you. Beyond this is a more challenging climb which would take between 15-20 minutes up some steep and rocky terrain before you reach the top where you will also be able to get drinks (not sure about prices here). We were awed by the breathtaking views and saw Little Adam's Peak which we had done the day before looking very diminutive and were suitably satisfied with ourselves for making it up to Ella Rock. It was a little tricky going down the steep bits but knowing that it was only going to be for a short distance was comforting. Overall I would highly recommend doing this and would most definitely recommend a moderate fitness level, good hiking shoes, sun protection, a towel to wipe off your perspiration, and plenty of water. I didn't think to bring my hiking poles but felt they would've come in handy at the last bit so if you have some foldable ones I would say take them along!

It's definitely tiring and takes a couple of hours to get up the rock and we would recommend going early morning or in the evening so that the sun is not out when you reach the top of the rock. We went in the morning (7.00 am). Just take water and maybe some food. Take regular breaks as well. It's a good way to burn your calories during a vacation!

This hike is enjoyable because of the unknowns. Should we really walk along the train track for a km? Are the local people directing me via their cafe? Is it ok to walk through the tea plantation? Should I follow the old barefooted farmer taking me through the 3m high grasses? And finally, in the last half hour, damn this is steep - why am I doing this?! Once at the top the views are superb and fresh juices are on offer. Do walk the extra 10 mins to the Buddhist shrine.

It is a moderate hike but super awesome views from the top. Best time to hike is the morning as its less tired and you will have the best views in the morning. If you get late fog will disturb your views. Though its is moderate hike, it is a thrilling experience. So worth doing the hike.

A really nice place to visit in Ella, Takes about 5km, from the center of Ella and 2hrs. better start early, so it is not so hot yet, take enough water with you, altough you can buy water and fruits from the top also. The path is goog, but quite steep at the top, so good shoes are recommended, saw people with flipflop's manage it still... the path is marked, but locals hamper with the markings to mislead people, and offer guidance service to the top, but map and route nformation is easy to find frm net, before journey, and they are very good.

I walked along the railroad track from Ella, which was fun - waved at trains going by. I left at 6 am to try and beat the heat, but wished I left earlier - 5.30 would have been better. It is super hot and the last 500-600m is very steep. One word of advise - don‚Äôt trust the locals (or signs) that tell you that there is a short cut. Another traveler and I were advised by some locals just after the black railway bridge to go a different way. We promptly got lost in the long grass and were ‚Äúrescued‚Äù by another local, who then demanded a fee. The easiest way is to follow the route outlined by the Aussieflashpacker bloggers -they give pictures - and the route is idiot proof. The entry point is a 5 min walk on the left of the tracks after the Kithalella train station (heading south) and is a hairpin turn. The view is stunning at the top.

Great hiking experience what was worth of every step. We started our way to Ella Rock from Kithalella railway station and landscape was beautiful. Climbing on Ella Rock had some steep parts but view on top was breathtaking. We spent some time on top before returned via railroad to Ella. Would recommend to visit there everyone! There is also fresh juice and fruits on top sometimes!

!!!PLEASE READ THIS!!! In a nutshell: complete RIP OFF. They TRICK you into getting a 'guide' and you CAN'T TRUST the signs. DON'T GO by sunset, we have met more than a few who got completely LOST in the woods (you can't see the sun anyway since it's on the other side of the mountain). My friends and I (three girls) wanted to climb the Ella rock without a guide for sunset. The tuctuc driver didn't drop us off at the usual spot and instead brought us to a shortcut. We only found out later and realised it was all part of their trick. There aren't any signs which way to walk and if there are signs, they're wrong. A local guy offered us that we could walk with him because he wanted to go there anyway. Long story short: In the end we wanted to thank him by paying him 600 LKR. First he played nice and refused the money but we insisted. He kept talking for a while and then we realised he wanted 3000 LKR. After a discussion he left agrily with the 600 LKR. We walked back with a couple who had to pay 400 LKR on the way up to a lady who told them the right way. When they didn't have more money, she led them wrong. We walked back to Ella on the train tracks for 45 minutes until someone told us that we were being followed by someone. It was the same guy who led us up to the rock accompanied by a friend. We don't know what their plan was but we made sure to stay with others all the way back.

We climbed the Ella Rock in the morning before the sun rise, it was pretty cool and nice in the morning, in the afternnoon it gets hot when the sun is up... take your snacks as there is nothing much on the way up in case you need a refreshment..

Once you've found the route, this is a pleasant hike through different environments, including tea plantation, forest, subalpine. There are 2 routes - a faster, more challenging route along the outer side of the hill, and a less strenuous longer route. Both require care, reasonable footwear, sun protection and water. The viewpoint can get very crowded. There is another viewpoint seen by a beautiful walk through the sun alpine forest area.

If you like hiking, this is for you. Ella Rock can be a little challenging to get to but is well worth it. We got a tuk tuk to Kital Ella train station, walked about 500m along railway lines (away from Ella) and then followed the path to the left towards the start of the hike. From here it is fairly well marked and you will see enough tourists to be able to find your way. It‚Äôs a challenging uphill on roughly marked and fairly loose soil so wear good shoes. Not suitable for anybody with significant mobility problems. View at the top is fantastic but what‚Äôs even better is the second view point a little further past the forest. Great place to pack a picnic for lunch if you plan on going during the day. Can thoroughly recommend!

Got up at 4am in the dark to trek and i must say that i was very unsure of what to expect! We hired a guid who cost 2000 Rupees but to be honest you could easily do it in a small group if you're not that confident. But the guide is recommended as he tooks us the safest and easiest route   The railway track takes you to a waterfall, where you start your climb through tea gardens and high grass. Te final 500 m is tough but my word is it worth it! The views are out of this world. Must do!

We walked up to the top of Ella Rock with our two children, aged 9 and 7. The walk takes around 3 hours and you can start it from the town of Ella. You walk along the railway lines, until you have crossed the metal bridge. From there you turn left down an embankment, across the river and turn right. You need to walk through very tall grasses and it is difficult to judge the pathway. Thankfully there are often other people who you can follow. I would advise using Maps.me which has a number of pathways plotted and saves you getting lost. The view from the top is beautiful and I would recommend going to both view points which are on different sides of the summit. The first viewpoint you reach has two fresh juice and coconut seller which is a lovely reward after your hard work. I would recommend wearing shoes with good grip. There are parts of the hike which are very steep for climbing and descending.

Hiked in the morning from Ella Station, starting along the tracks and then taking a sharp left a short way after the next station. This takes you onto a bridge over a small river. After this you can go left or right. I chose left as advised by my guesthouse, it really was a quite straightforward route from there although the final ascent is steep! Once at the top you are rewarded with some great views. It's also really worth carrying on the the further view point and small cave temple too. Best to hike early in the morning or late afternoon to avoid the heat.

Wow the views from the top are amazing. It worth all the long walk in the railway, between tea plantation, eucalyptus, we had everything. We were gently guided to the top by a nice dog, and if the weather is wet be aware of leeches, they are there waiting for you.

We accessed the rock by going almost vertically from the road outside our hotel, negotiating our way through mountain villages, getting lost, enjoying the most spectacular views and scenery.  We climbed 198 floors (on the phone) and it was a hard slog but well worth it.  The view at the top is wonderful.  There are 2 stalls serving king coconut, juices and smoothies for a very reasonable sum.  The walk through the forest and tea plantation was magical.  Definitely one of our walking highlights in Ella.

The way until you reach the top is hard, but there are some little shops. It is important to take a map with you because the path is not well marked. The views are incredible at the top, and you can enjoy some juice and coconut there. We also recommend to visit the little temple, also for the views.

I personally didn't love Sri Lanka, bur the view from the train and this trek were my best! the way and the view is very nice, just be very careful because they love to walk in the rails of the train making it as a normal thing but sometimes is very dangerous.

This is a great hike with excellent views from the top and along the way. It takes about 2 hours each way from Ella railway station and the latter section of the walk is fairly steep and rugged going but should be manageable for most people. We‚Äôre in our late-50s and of average fitness and we got up there ok. The route is really quite. Follow the railway tracks from Ella railway station in the direction of Kandy for about 40 minutes to Kitalella station. About 200 metres beyond Kitalella there is a track on the left that makes a had u-turn back on itself. Take this and cross the bridge over the waterfall. Immediately after the bridge take a left fork. This is the place where you may go working as the right hand fork appears to be the main track and even has a white signpost to the rock. Ignore this and instead look up the hillside for a yellow sign for ‚ÄúElla Rock - Map Route‚Äù and head towards this. Thereafter it‚Äôs just a matter of following this track without deviation. You‚Äôll wander through a lovely tea plantation to start with and about half way you will pass a cafe/shop on the left. After this the going starts to get tougher. Just keep going and you‚Äôll get there. One important point, just before Kitalella station there are touts who will try to divert you on an alternative route and offer to guide you for a price. Just ignore them and keep on with these directions. Once at the summit the views are superb but the area isn‚Äôt huge and can get crowded. If you pass the summit t9 the right and walk on through the woods then after about 10 minutes you will come to a second and lessvisited viewpoint.

The hike starts down the rail roads and leads into the woods and up the mountain. We went without a guide as there were many people doing the hike so we basically teamed up with them when we were in doubt of the way. The view of the top is very beautiful. The climb is very hard and exhausting so if you don‚Äôt walk that good we would not recommend the trip! At the top the locals are selling fruit and refreshments. We saw a lizard on the way.

It seems kinda far. People said it‚Äôs a 5 hour walk up and down. But we did it in 2,5.. make sure you check your map and you take the right paths to walk up there! Very beautiful scenic view at the top! Be carefull with rain!

I enjoyed hiking Ella Rock! It was quite the challenge. I used Maps.Me to help navigate. I turned down a few local guides. I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs necessary to hire a guide, but on my way back I got lost, which was quite unpleasant. I would say that none of the visible trail markers are available. I went by the guideposts in the train track. In retrospect, I wish I would have taken a tuk tuk to the entrance to conserve energy for the hike. The last 30-50 minutes were straight up hill on a jagged path. As I mentioned, it‚Äôs worth it. However, I‚Äôm glad I finished this in my youth; it was intense.
It is a challenging climb but the rewarding scene at the top is worth the effort. Beware of local scammers who will trick you to go on a wrong track and then offer their services to act as guides...

Challenging as it‚Äôs pretty steep but it‚Äôs well worth it when you get to the top and see that view!! There are no sign posts on your way up, but if you google search ‚ÄúGap year escape Ella rock‚Äù there is a step by step guide with photos and instructions to help you get there. If you get confused, just go up! Some people get a guide so there‚Äôs that option if you want. Takes about 3 hours round trip.

My wife and I (both 27) climbed this last week. It is a relatively tough walk to the top but the views are amazing and totally worth it. The only downside it that one section of the route is difficult to follow. It is not worth paying a guide, but be prepared to give the locals a small tip to help you out. The start of the path (45mins) is along the train tracks which is really cool (and safer than it sounds). A short distance from the tracks is Kithal Ella falls which are quite beautiful. The lonely planet guide book suggests you climb from there however this section is impossible to follow so we recommend you return to the train tracks and continue on for a short while until you reach the main path. We tried to climb from the falls and got very lost in thick jungle and had to tip a local to take us up to the main path. Once you are back on the main path the bulk of the climb is very easy to follow. The path is well worn with lots of groups heading up, but it is loose in places and so good footwear (trainers or better) is essential. Don't wear flip flops. The views at the top are amazing, and there is a second viewing platform another 15 mins on if you continue on the same path. The total climb took us 1.5 hours as we are regular hikers and quite fit. I would expect for it to take 2 - 2.5 hours if you don't hike regularly. Overall this was a fantastic climb with amazing views at the top which we recommend to everyone able to do it.

A good challenging hike up to the top and a fun walk along the railway with a close up of the famous Sri Lankan train going past for us! Amazing views at the top are well worth the effort to get there! Didn‚Äôt find any real need for a guide on our walk as the online instructions from a variety of sources make it obvious. Another must do whilst in Ella.

We went up there from Kithalella and had about 2 hours, including taking pictures and a break on top. If you start at Kithalella you can spare yourself some "guides" that only want your money, we didnt meet one of them. We did our tour without a guide and without problems, just make sure you know the way in advance. The hike is not really a challenge (but we're swiss so...:))  but the view is amazing. I recommend to start at 8.00, we only saw 6 other people while hiking the way up but while getting back down at the tracks we met many many crowds!

Classic hike to do when in Ella and lives up to the hype, stunning views and good little challenging walk too. We started climbing at 8am from our guesthouse which is 20 mins from Kithalella train station, we were up the top by 9 30 even after wasting 15 mins getting a bit lost. It is easy to miss the left hand turn off the railways tracks so pay attention to landmarks along the way if you are using a map that lists the landmarks like Buddha and bench, they‚Äôre not huge structures on the side of the tracks. At the end of the hike up there is about 20 mins of fairly steep climbing towards the top or can go a slightly longer way that isn‚Äôt quite as steep. It got a bit misty and rainy mid morning when we were coming back down, it did clear by lunchtime tho.

Can complete the hike within 3 hours. The scenery from the top of Ella Rock is Amazing and it is surely rewarding. You could see far and wide across the valley. It might be bit difficult to find the correct path. Other than that everything is fine. Try to start your journey  early in the morning.

We began at the train station and needed 2.5 hours total. We had downloaded an app to prevent us from getting lost. The app was spot on, but then again so were the signs that were directing us. We didnt see any fake signs which habe been described by others. The climb, in my opinion was rather easy. We did it in the heat of the day and were still suprised by how many people were on the trail. The views were stunning and well worth it. Can only further recommend "viewranger" before setting off. We met many many people that had been lost 3-4 hours before finding the top.

Finding Ella rock took us a little bit of effort GPS was unreliable and our homestay provided us with a hand drawn map. To top it off locals constantly guide you to 'shotcuts' that take you through narrow paths that cut through high grass, private property and tea fields. To be fair I do think it is a shortcut because coming back it only took us a few minutes to walk, but on the way there we have no idea where we are going and there just happens to be a bunch of guides who offer to show you the way for some cash. We decided to pay for a guide and once we were at the base of the hill, it's a fairly tough climb up to the top. At the top there were some merchants selling water and juice. The top provides a great view of the hill country. Note that you will most likely walk the train tracks so keep an ear out.

Amazing hike who is interested in hiking of the purpose of your visit ,there are too many ways to get on the top but we followed the hardest way and came back thorough easiest way on the railway I guess .

Nice walk along the tracks, ending in a very strap jungle hill. Tough but worth it! We arrived to the top at 2pm and was very lucky to see the full view. Best to do the climb in the morning. Very challenging and adventurous walk Take good shoes, water and don‚Äôt take risks near the cliff edges that instagram pic isn‚Äôt worth it.... think about where is the rescue service and the nearest hospital that you want to be treated in? Follow the leads on TA and take the written guides with you otherwise you will be at the mercy of the rouges ‚Äúthe guides‚Äù Find the cafe and your almost there Friendly local Police patrol the paths and are will to chat and help.

We started out from our guesthouse with some instructions that we followed but were lost amongst all the paths in the long grass and through the tea plantations! Great walk through tea plantations and forest with rewarding views. It's reasonably strenuous but not overly demanding

This is a fun hike if you don't mind traveling off the beaten path. The route can be followed easily by using a handwritten map posted by previous reviewers. I would recommend hiking in the morning to avoid the afternoon heat.

The walk to the Ella Rock was nice. You could walk through the tea plantation or through the woods. At Ella Rock, there is an enterprising family selling drinks and coconuts. Long way to walk and its bit sweaty initially. But when you reach the peak its amazing. Such a beautiful view. There are many things to do in Ella. Its a happening place

Tough hike, but the view is amazing. We did Ella rock the day before little Adams peak. The view is amazing and they sell really Nice juices on the top! Tip: Go at the top 300m to the right and you got another great view

Totally worth the sweat. The touts are a pain, trying to send you the wrong way so you pay them. But our hotel manager showed us photos and it is easy to follow the route once you know. Walking the rail tracks is unique...you‚Äôd get arrested in the UK! We saw some monkeys on the tracks and working way up through tea plantations to the forest and then the peak. Looking down on Ella and Little Addams peak. Sweeeeeet as.

A good idea is to start the climb early we started at 8 am. Went up waterfall road kept left at Zion View, and when you get to the railway you go on them just over the black bridge and then turn left and start the climb.:) map me is an app, who can lead the way, or you can hire a guide.
Well worth the effort, fantastic views from the top, not too overcrowded and fun to walk along the railwaybtracks. Awesome day out.

In order to catch the sunrise on the back of a lush mountain ridge, you will need to start the climb at least by 4am. This is because it‚Äôs approximately 2hrs of a climb to summit. (Depending on fitness level this could reduce). You can also minimise your time in the hot sun by having an early start. If you want to play safe, take a guide. The view from the top is breathtaking and fully worth the time and effort.
Great views when you get there. Beware the ‚Äúrogue‚Äù guides who take you the long way round past their cafes ! When you get to the top there are locals selling fresh lemon and orange juice.

The walk up here wasn‚Äôt difficult if you are moderately fit and didn‚Äôt take that long. Approx 2 1/2 hours round trip. The  last 20 mins of the walk can be a bit taxing and the ground is uneven and a bit slippery in places. You need to be careful on the descent. However it‚Äôs a nice walk and well worth it for the lovely views. There are local drinks to purchase on the top; appreciated on a hot day!

The route to the top isn‚Äôt too difficult - until you get onto the main paths to the top from the trainline there are quite a few options to take but as long as you keep ascending you‚Äôll get there. We went the wrong way and just as we were retracing our steps to find the correct route a local guide appeared out of nowhere. If you do need a bit of help at the beginning I‚Äôd recommend you ask the guide to leave once you‚Äôre on the main paths. There are so many people on the mountain that it‚Äôs very difficult to get lost unless you are on it in poor light. Views from the top and sense of achievement were stunning.

We started to go by rails and it took much longer than expected. We went for about 1 hour by rails only. I was ready for Ella Rock with a map and good explanation of how to reach the top. I was very confident but the way was much more tricky than I expected! We almost lost a few times and had a few disagreements about the way to go. But we did it without the guide. The whole process and such a long way gave us a lot of confidence and good feeling. Girls rules!

Two friends, my wife, little son and I climbed Ella Rock in August. The hike is challenging but definitely feasible (I was carrying our son and my wife our backpack) and totally worth the effort. After reaching the top, the view across Ella and the surrounding area is brilliant and somehow it's not too crowded so that you can definitely enjoy the atmosphere (however, we started our tour arround 7.30 am, i.e. less tourists were on their way to the top).
