So.. this is definitely not your typical hike which makes it even better. As many of the other reviewers said you should use a guide or ask for very specific directions before hand as parts of it is off the beaten track almost. You begin at the train tracks and take a sharp turn to the left after a few km ,you then shortly pass through peoples farms and houses and greeted by friendly smiles from the locals.Its best to start off early and carry lots of water. Good trainers recommended although the locals go all the way up the steep slopes with flip flops!The view at the top is well worth it!Great photo opportunities. Before descending there's  a Buddha statue in a little cave  that shouldn't be missed.Definitely one of the highlights of the trip.

Make sure if you go you go with a guide or with a local people or in a group. there are many signs on the way, but most of them, it s a trap to get guide by the local people to guide you and to pay them tips.

I had been in Ella rock on 25th of August 2018 with my clients from Australia and it was a pretty amazing hike. To get there normally 1.5 hours quite steep tracking but eventually get there amazing view and you feel it's worth of being there. And specially if you are doing without a help of a tracker better to take a map. Sometimes when you go by your self they try to mislead us.
a short climb up, with a lot of sceninc views. get enough water and take your time on top to enjoy the view.

Just like the other reviews say, when waking along the railroad, you will go over a metal constructed bridge  and then approach a small Buddhist shrine in your left.  A few locals hang out here and try to direct you off the railroad at this point.   DON‚ÄôT leave at this point, tell them thank you bu walk on.   You will go past a train station and then a few hundred metres after the station on your left hand side, look out for a rock with a U shaped dirt path.   Take this path.  You will then cross over a bridge and see signs for Ella rock - all pointing you in different directions!    We took the right hand side and made it and on our descent we ended up on the path that would of been the left hand path they all pretty much take you there. On the right hand path we approached the ‚Äòfarmers restaurant‚Äô and at this point where the path forked again we kept right almost doing a U turn around the field by the restaurant.  About 40 meters you can see a house built just about you and a path leading up to this - take this path. I have recorded the route on my garmin device so will make this available if anyone would like it (through garmin) We‚Äôre not the fittest or experienced and as long as you‚Äôre prepared for a good walk with a little bit of perseverance then it‚Äôs worth it.    The last 10 mins of the climb is pretty steep but it‚Äôs all worth it at the end. There are some vendors at the top selling coconut, orange juices and water 200LKR each.   Believe me, it‚Äôs needed! Take sun screen and water on your trip and Wes good footwear. The views are spectacular!

If you're reasonably fit and don't mind a few hours walking in the heat, this is a must-do while visiting Ella. You walk from your accommodation so stay close to the centre, or on the western side of Ella to save a bit of walking time. We left Ella Rock House around 8:30am and walked up via Waterfall Road, crossing onto the train tracks where they are only a couple of metres from the road. From there we walked through to Kital Ella station and kept a lookout for the "tea road" which is a sharp turn back to the left a couple of hundred metres past Kital Ella station. The tea road is a wider walking track than various other walking tracks exiting the railway. After a short distance on the tea road, there's a bridge across the river and then you're in the tea plantations and starting to climb. Almost immediately you reach a junction with signs pointing to the "map main road" to the left and to the "nearest road" to the right. The "map main road" is the most obvious route with the biggest volume of traffic so it's hard to get lost if you take this route. We took the "nearest road" which is a short-cut and we had a Sri-Lankan in our party so when the obvious route disappeared, there were no more signs and we found ourselves in an old lady's back yard, he was able to get directions quickly and without any issues. We walked off-track for a short distance but by that time we could see walkers on the main route so it was just a matter of following a ridgeline through open forest to connect. It was a very nice route through market gardens as well as tea plantations and definitely shorter and cooler than the main route but best to go with a local if heading that way. We connected with the main route at an open point that we'd seen the previous day from Little Adams Peak, with open eucalyptus forest behind us. After a few pics we started the main climbing section, which is a bit arduous but okay if you don't push too hard. We were at the top before 11am and the views were definitely worth the effort. We enjoyed fresh coconuts before walking another 250m or so to a shrine and another look-out which was also spectacular. We started our walk back down the road section a bit further to look at a track we'd seen a couple of guides use. It was a bit longer but not as arduous as the main track, I would stay with the main track rather than take this route if going up again. We followed the main route the rest of the way back, definitely obvious all the way down so if walking without a guide or a local friend it's the best option.
A place worth to visit. Don't forget to take a train ride to go to Ella.. Mist, drizzling, cool breeze and hiking ‚ù§Ô∏è You'll never regret it.

I nearly talked myself out of going up Ella Rock when I actually saw it when I arrived in Ella. I'm glad I didn't, though. The climb was OK until you got near the top, then it got much harder and steeper. It was well worth it, though! Do: Get up early! I left about 7.30am and it was reasonably quiet at the top. By the time I was heading down, there was almost a constant stream of people going up and I can imagine it got quite packed at the top! Do your research before you go - it's perfectly do-able without a guide, but you need to know where you're going and what markers to look for so that you don't get lost/ led astray by 'locals' or conned into taking on someone as a guide part way up! There are some detailed directions in some of the TripAdvisor reviews, which worked for me. You'll probably also see other walkers along the way who you can check with. Go with someone else - I started off on my own and, thankfully, met another lady on her own soon after I started. I would have felt like an easy target for some of the people trying to become 'guides' on the way up had I been on my own and some parts are quite secluded. Plus, it's more fun with company! Take a camera - the views are spectacular! And there are some lovely view points along the way too. Take PLENTY of water and some snacks! Take a walk along the top - there's a shrine and another lookout point another easy 5-10 minute walk to the right of where you first arrive at the top. Don't: Get misled by the 'locals' who are trying to tell you where to go - have directions you trust and stick to them! Fret about how to get back down - we ended up going back down a different way, but as long as you know you're heading towards the train tracks, you'll be fine!

We trekked up Ella Rock on a hot day in July. It‚Äôs a well trodden path which many tourists take. The trek starts along the railway line before heading through tea fields and into woods at which point it gets much steeper. In the heat it gets quite hard work but by no means impossible if you pace yourself. Take plenty of water and wear sensible footwear! The view at the top was well worth the effort. On the way back down, just before you reach the train line, you take a small bridge over a river where you can take your shoes and socks off to dangle your feet in the cool water. We then went a few yards further downstream where there were some water pools where we had a very refreshing swim. If you go further still there‚Äôs a large waterfall; take care if there‚Äôs been a lot of rain.

We enjoyed the hike, it took 1,5h from Ella centre. If you are sportive, the last part is no problem, but we saw a few people struggling with this last part. The view is nice and on the top fresh coconut and juices are waiting for you. We followed the map attached to this comment. Many paths lead to Ella rock, so do not get nervous if locals want to show you the "right" way.

4 hours to go there and back.  Only the last 200 meters are really difficult.  This is really worth when you arrive there and see the view over Ella, the valley and Little Adam's Peak.  Don't forget to get there through the railways.

An easy hike if you learned the trek beforehand. Don't be swayed by wannabe guides hanging around. They tend to confuse foreign travellers with false trails. Use the trek to the left just after Kithala Ella station. Carry enough water.

Lots of people do this walk and many start early.  You don't need a guide, just follow the crowds.  Look out for locals who will suggest the right way, and then ask for money when they miraculously "help" you find your way back on to the well worn path.  Sensible shoes are a must as it is steep and rocky in places. Small river on the way down, just as you reach the railway, is ideal for cooling off in, so pack some swimwear or get your undies wet. Allow 4 hours for leisurely round trip.

Ella Rock is one of the must-sees in Ella, a place which is becoming increasingly touristy and even brands itself as a 'tourist town' (check out the signboards at the junction!). Great Amazing view of the southern valley/province from the top of the mountain.  From the top of the mountain.  It takes only about 2 hours to the top if you do not miss the route.  At times it takes foggy but, it clears very quick and could see far distance. Do not miss to visit Ella Rock,   if you happen to travel to Ella.  Its an Amazing View. Just one request to the traveler who goes up to the mountain  for enjoy the view: Please do not spoil the enviornment. (Do not throw away any plastic bottles or any other disposable  items.) Protect to the next traveler and for our children. A. Rozario

Hike takes approximately 45 minutes up. A bit trickier than little Adam's peak but definitely worth it. First you go through the tea plantations and then you climb up through the forest. We started at 7 am so it wasn't that hit yet. Amazing view - we even saw some eagles :)

We started climbing the rock at 7 am. We did not hire any guides as there were many tourists as well as locals heading towards Ella rock and we followed the same path. We trusted him and stayed. He was  correct. It got cleared around 11.15am and we were able to capture many of the beautiful pictures. A must go !! It is a heaven on earth.

If you follow atlas and boots route guide you won‚Äôt get lost. Many people were sent the wrong way. This is a lovely walk and worth the views at the top. Go a little further thru the gum forest to a Buddha cave and great view to the water fall

This is most closet view of ella waterfalls. Sunrises over mountains (especially the ones in Ella) are nothing short of stunning: so we recommend a super early start to your day. Many people begin the hike from the Ella Railway Station, but you'd save about half an hour or more if you begin it at the Kithal-Ella Station, which you'll be passing regardless of where you start.

Awesome. We set out from central Ella at about 8.00am which was good timing because later in the day could be too hit and more crowded. The walk was fantastic - it started off heading up a street off the main drag and then we walked along the train line for a while before reaching the trail. The walk takes you on different terrains and levels - sometimes it flattens out and at other a steep climb. We did this hike from our hotel to Ella rock and I have to say it was stunning!!We walked along the tracks, over the bridge and through the tea plantation. There is a steep climb at the end but the view is incredible! Take lots and lots of water because it gets very hot. We read about the route online before we set off - there are 3 different routes, some easier than others to follow but overall quite straight forward.

We love doing things without a guide where possible and read that you could walk Ella Rock without one so decided to give it a go. We followed the Atlas and Boots blog which was really helpful. At one point we were a little unsure on which path to take so we waited and took some water and a group of people passed so we checked the way with them. The route takes you through some relaxing tea plantations before getting steeper and for the last bit you are scrabbling up rocks... totally doable though. When you reach the top it is so worth it for the view! We made friends with a dog halfway up and he stayed with us until we reached the top... I think he belonged to the people who have a cafe on the top, he was really friendly. Watch out for monkeys at the top! The walk back down is much more relaxing.

Ella rock is a frequently visiting place of tourists at Ella. It forms one side of Ella gap. There are few pathways to reach the peak. We started the walk at 10am and got to the top around 12.30. Followed route listed on the blog ‚Äòatlas and boots‚Äô - would recommend using that! A few places selling drinks along the way but would recommend taking water, snacks and some wipes with you. You don‚Äôt need fancy walking shoes, trainers are fine but watch for the slippy ground on the final steep incline. The fresh juice stands at the top we‚Äôre most welcome! For the average fairly fit person I would say the climb is moderate!

The last climb will try and break you, but the stunning panoramic views are what everyone comes here for! You don‚Äôt need a guide, unless you go for sunrise. I left at 8am so passed the super early rises on their way down but importantly beat a lot of other people up there. If you haven‚Äôt already, download the app Maps.Me as the paths there are accurate. One guide I saw had no clue and started asking me for directions so don‚Äôt fork out. Note you can buy beverages at the top if you need!

Starting early to beat the heat is essential and makes this a worthwhile climb. Guide generally worthwhile but with its popularity you can‚Äôt go to wrong. Would recommend it to hikers and casual walkers

We did the walk with our 7 and 9 year old daughters. It is 1,5h 1 way. Count 4,5h for the whole visit. We left at 8.30. If you can leave earlier it is better. We didnit take a guide. Just google ‚Äòella rock hike‚Äô and you ll find multiple self-drawn maps/descriptions. Totally worked for us. Unsure alibg the wat? Just ask a local on the path. You leave at Malpe restaurant and then walk for 30min on the railroad track. As you walk in the supports of the railroad track it gives good rythm to sing songs with your kids, an extra motivation. Bring hats and min 1,5l water for a family of 4. Some fruit or cookies too. Don t worry. There are 3 places along the way where you can buy more water /fruit if needed. After the railroad track you cross a bridge and go into the tea plantations,high grass afterwards and eucalyptus trees after that. The last 400m is a steep climb, and then you arrive at the viewpoint. It is breathtaking! And yes: there are locals selling fresh juices. On the way down we toon another path leading us to a waterfall where swimming is possible. I recommend it. Ask one of the locals for the way. Enjoy the trip.

OMG, I‚Äôm pretty sure it was the exact same man who saved my friends and I when we were trying to climb it! Such a beautiful place üôÇ The truth is that if you look up information online about Ella Rock you will find all kinds of opinions. Many people say that it is very easy to get lost and many others say that with a simple hand-drawn map it can be done without problems. Others say it is necessary to take a local guide and others say that it is not at all. Finally, others say it takes you three hours up and down, and others will say double. So seeing such confusion and little concrete information, I decided to write this guide on how I easily climbed the Ella Rock.

We had a great time climbing Ella Rock but have some recommendations for other visitors. 1) look online for a proper route. We used a very helpful blog caled Atlas and Boots which was very accurate. We also downloaded an app called map me which was also useful in case you did get lost. 2) when you are walking on the tracks ignore all signs telling you to turn left before kithalella station. We saw red signs on the tracks showing this. There are also locals sat near a white structure who also tell you to turn left at this point - ignore them as it is not the right way to go. You need to continue down the tracks, past kithalella station. There are small white waymarker signs along the track. Walk past the 166 1/2 sign, there is then a sharp turn to the left which is almost slightly back on yourself but take that. If you walk to 166 1/4 you have gone too far! 3) When you reach the top, i cannot recommend walking slightly further to the viewpoint from the 'cave temple. It is along an easy path but in my opinion has better views and is less busy!

A great place to hike but start early as possible as it is a hot and steep climb, especially towards the top. We got told the wrong way by a local and then got lost. Out of nowhere a different local appeared and helped us and then asked for money. Go left after the waterfall bridge!

There‚Äôs a couple of men working the route telling tourists they have taken a wrong turn then leading them a different way (albeit still to the top) and insisting on payment (5000-/). This nearly happened to us however  we firmly said we would find our own way. We came across two other travellers who had the same experience. In both cases the gentlemen said they weren‚Äôt guides they were farmers. Be sure to check the route and be cautious if anyone is trying to lead you a certain way. It‚Äôs the first time we have had such an experience in Sri Lanka.

Don't get a guide for this, you can easily do this hike alone. You must do this hike when you are in Ella! Although I would not recommend this hike with small kids or kids over 8 years old who are very whiny. Some tips: - take a picture of the train hours, so you know when to expect a train on the tracks you will be walking. - go early. It gets crowded at the top around noon. This is dangerous and not ideal for pictures. - wear sunscreen. The walk on the tracks is with little or no shade, the walk up Ella rock however is true the forest so you will not have a lot of sunshine. - don't listen too local guys who give you directions without you asking them. They could trick you, so you get lost and feel desperate enough to hire them as a guide - you have to pass 1 train station. Than you continue to follow the tracks (you will have rock on your right side and vegitation on your left side) and after a few minutes you will see a path on your left side. It's very easy to miss because it's a very sharp turn do pay attention. This is when you have to leave the tracks and enter the forest. I used some blogs too find my way. I highly recommend you do some research and use a blog aswell because it's easy to get lost. But that makes it more of an adventure, right? The hike took us about 4 hours in total.

Being moderately fit will help, but by hiking standards I think this is probably deemed an easy to moderate climb. The varying vistas along the way plus the spectacular view at the top make it a 'must do' hike.   The heat makes it a bit tougher but there are plenty of places to catch some welcome breeze along the way, and I recommend setting out earlier in the day. We left at 8am and felt sorry for those only starting out at 11am. I found it a little tough (not a hiker) but the rest of the family were fine. Allow about 3-4 hours so you can spend some time relaxing and taking in the spectacular view at the top (and along the way) - the reward for your efforts. We set off on foot from the centre of Ella along the train tracks for quite a long way to the base of the hill.  We had our driver as a guide but I did not see another option and there was a steady stream of hikers doing the same.  The walk along the tracks was interesting and enjoyable - past homestays, farms and we spotted lots of birds, butterflies and the occasional monkey. It would have been quite confusing to know where to go. Many tourists seemed to get lost, and resorted to hiring a 'guide' on the way up.  They didn't look happy.  Others spotted us with our Sri Lankan driver and tagged along (clever).  As you would expect it is a climb and I found it challenging towards the very end where the terrain is quite steep. Before that was okay.  Bring water, but there is a spot towards the top (before the last steep climb) to buy drinks, and you can buy water or fresh coconut at the very top. Terrain includes railway tracks, packed dirt, steps, rocks - but it was a little slippery so good shoes with grip required. We were able to lightly jog some of the way down!  Very worthwhile - lots of amazing vistas at every step.

We had actually made plans to just walk to Ella rock on our own, we had a driver (whom had never been to Ella rock) who insisted on taking us to Ella rock.... big mistake. We were directed to routes that were nothing like the indicators on many bloggers websites. We ended up walking through pathways that clearly had no visitors go through. At this point a ‚Äútracker‚Äù arrived who took us to Ella rock. We trekked through pathways that were not pathways. I am 99% certain we took the incredibly convoluted and unnecessary route as a result of locals directing our driver. This was unfortunate. Otherwise the railway portion of this walk was so incredibly enjoyable. Best time of the day would have to be the early morning. I do not recommend leaving mid morning. We saw many tourists on their way up close to 11am with a solid 2hours uphill walking still to go. The heat makes it a harder walk, be kind to yourself.

Ella rock is the main hiking attraction in Ella other than the little Adams peak. But this is much harder to climb. But if you are in good health you can do it without much hassle. It‚Äôs not hard to find the route. Walk from Ella railway station towards kandy side. After about 2km you will find the kithala ella sub station. Just after the station there‚Äôs a path to your left in the shape of a ‚ÄòU‚Äô. Go through it and after the bridge take the left which goes up towards the tea fields. Locals might trick you and show wrong paths and will charge you to take you to top once you get lost. You don‚Äôt need a guid to climb Ella rock. Final part of the climb is challenging but doable. Within 2 hours of time you will be able to reach top. Carry plenty of water and some light snacks. There are some vendors at top as well but their price can be very high. Views are awesome from the top. Just in front of you would be the little Adams peak and you can see some distance from the top. There‚Äôs another view point also in a distance of about 800m from the main view point. Don‚Äôt forget to reach there as well. Views are much better from there. You can see the upper part of ravana falls also from this second view point. Try to do the climb in morning time before it gets hot.
A decent hike and easy enough if you are reasonably fit. No need for a guide and don't listen to the locals that try to 'help' you. It has great views at the top. Took us 4 hours return.

Normally it will take few hours to hike the ella rock when you start it from the ella town. Village people will come to help you to show the road and you need to pay them some reasonable amount. Some are quite good but most of them are just bad following only the money. There will be ticket counter at the edge of the ella rock.(They were building it when i was traveling last time) The view is so beautiful when you reach the top.

It seems that a lot of people seem to get lost on their way so I thought I would help. Firstly you need to go along the train tracks. This is a route that anyone in town can show you. Keep walking along the train tracks for a while. You will come across a black bridge which you must cross. Continue on. There is a Bodhi tree (white thing at the bottom) on your left with a Buddha statue there. There are people there that will offer to help you. They are scammers and were extremely abusive to me when I said we were fine. Please note that these people are not from Ella. They are people from other villages trying to trick tourists. The people from Ella are wonderful. Continue along the tracks passed Kithalella train station which is on your right. It‚Äôs hard to miss. Keep going along the tracks. If you see a white sign with 166 1/2, you are on the right track. Eventually you will come to a dirt road on your left. This will eventually lead you to a small bridge. At the end of that bridge go LEFT. There is a sign to go right but I think it leads to a cafe rather than the desired destination. From there you are on your way to the top. It‚Äôs a beautiful view. It is a difficult climb, especially in the heat so I suggest starting early. The locals selling juice and water are all very lovely.

Ella Rock is a ubiquitous feature on any visitor to the area‚Äôs to-do list; and it‚Äôs well worth it. As described in other reviews, the trail is accesible via the train tracks after the bridge and station, to the left. Locals will discreetly offer to help you, and this is useful as the initial section is confusing and moreover skirts around private land; giving these volunteers a contribution is a kind gesture and supports the locals (500). I don‚Äôt agree with others that view this as a scam. Once at the top, and having soaked in the view from the left, don‚Äôt forget to go to the right along the large path and then down to the left to see the lookout point and the cave with the shrine. If you‚Äôre there early enough, consider waking on along the tree-lined edge down to Ravana‚Äôs Secret (see profile on Tripadvisor)where, for a small fee, you can use the privately-accesible waterfalls visible from the viewpoint and tour the wonderful property.

We hiked here from Amba tea estate all the way back to Ella. It was a great hike, about 4 hours in total and we also went via upper ravana falls (much better than the low ones on the road). We enjoyed this not just being a there-and-back from Ella town. Attached are the walking directions from Amba (where you can get a tea tour first!)

If it‚Äôs high season you probably won‚Äôt have any trouble finding the path since there will plenty of people walking it, but if you‚Äôre going at a slower time make sure you use the internet to brush up on the path ahead of time since it‚Äôs not marked. The eucalyptus groves when you reach the higher elevation are really lovely and smell so nice.

This was one of our favourite things we did in Sri Lanka (we do like to be active though!) it took about 5 hours in total for us and we were lucky to bump in to someone on the way who gave us tips on the route. We have expected it to be clearly signposted but this isn‚Äôt the case so do your research before you go (one route is signposted but this isn‚Äôt main way and locals will take you off main path and charge you!) the walk has amazing views along the railway line, through tea plantations and whilst it is hot it is only really the last part of the climb that gets tough. If you have a day this is definitely worth doing - our highlight of Ella for sure!) and the view from the top is incredible!

This walk/climb is really complete. You start walking on traintracks which is cool. You can chill in a rapid about halfway on the walk part of the trail. You pass through teaplantations. The view from Ella Rock is beautiful and totally worth the sweat.
Coming from the town side is hard and you go up and back the same way. We started on the other side with a guide and it was a very pleasant hike. Glad we started in one place and ended up in Ella.

Many different routes to reach the top, we had our best trail routes (bit too technical for me but fun) from our host.  Steep at the end so be careful. No directions towards Ella rock hence beware of villagers trying to direct you and asking for small token in return. Magnificent views at the top...loving it.

We hiked Ella Rock with the kids, starting from the homestay we slept at. We thought it would be easy, but with the kids it was actually rather difficult ‚Äì even if we we had tougher hikes in the past. I suppose it was because of the heat and the humidity, event though we started at 07.30 in the morning. Anyway, it was 12 Km ‚Äì since we went until we reached the Buddha statue at the top. Elevation ascent of about 350m. Four hours in total. A lot of walking on the train tracks ‚Äì which was rather cool. We followed the instructions on the Atlas & Boots blog ‚Äì as advised on the night before by someone at the cooking class. And it worked just fine. On the way back we stopped at a place on the way to drink coconuts and relax - it was rather cool.

First of all you probably don‚Äôt need a guide as you‚Äôll find your way sooner or later as it is pretty straight forward where to go. Once you reach the first checkpoint (they sell food and cold water out of sheds along the way). We got scammed by this lady who led us astray at first, getting us good and lost and then wanted money to guide us to the top. We payed 3000 rp for this. The view was really nice though. But watch out.

We started at kithalella station. We drove there with the scooter and started climbing at 0550. This was a little late to see the sunrise, but we had perfect views. In oreperation of this trip we've read many descriptions on how to get to the summit. It seems there are many ways to go to the top. If you use maps.me, a guide is definately not needed! There are some  paths on maps.me that have been  disapered. We took the bridge before the station and over the waterfall and then the shortest route up. After the sights at ella rock, do not hesitate to stop there. A bare 10 minute walk away is an even prettier view of the valley and the ravana waterfall.

To get to start of hike from ella station walk on train tracks towards Kandy side until you see a black bridge (picture). After you pass the black bridge you will see a steps on your left (coconut vendor). Take those steps and follow road and you see another bridge with a view of waterfall down on left. End of bridge you will see two pathways both on your left and right that take you to Ella rock. Right one is short and goes through jungle. Left one has beautiful views but seems long. Both paths meet at common point where you can clearly see little adams peak on left. From there its a steep hike to top of rock. We got lost and ended up hiring a villager for 1500 rupees for trip guidance. Since it was early morning time we did not have much hikers to follow. On plus side we got to top from short side and came back from view side with support of our guide. Couple of other points: wear long sleeve to protect yourself from thorns and bushes. Until you make it to steep part there is not much shade so better to start early. There is option to directly go to Rawana Cave and Rawana temple if that is part of itinerary and then take a bus or tuk from there. Enjoy!

We took the route following the train tracks, in total we took about 5 hours. Dont get distracted by the people along the road telling you where to go, they often misguide you trying to get money. Online there are websites with photos of the track to help you get there. Amazing views, maybe the most beautiful ive ever seen.

This is quite a decent hike to get to the top but it was good fun and worth doing while in Ella. The view is lovely. Can be a bit hard to find the track but I really don't think a guide is necessary. The locals are very helpful at pointing you in the right direction and if you have maps.me or something similar it is not too hard. Steep at the end so best to do earlier in the day when its cooler and wear walking shoes!
Lovely hike, not too difficult, interesting through the farm fields, fantastic views, you can buy water, tea and coconuts at the top. Excellent experience.

Ella rock was a nice highlight of out stay in Ella. The view is very nice but not mind blowing(in my opnion). But whenever you are in Ella definetly worth doing! Make sure you go there by following the train tracks and turn left at a pretty obvious side path of the train track (check this on internet or with your host). Dont get send of by locals telling you ‚ÄúElla Rock is that way‚Äù, you will get lost another local will ‚Äúbump‚Äù in to you and guide you to Ella Rock and you will need to pay them. We took a little tour because of this wich costed us 2 hours and lots of energy. Make sure you figure out how to walk before you go. Take water with you, it will be hot. There is a chance to buy water along the way!
Even if you don't like hiking, you should try this hike and confience me that the view is not worth walking ; )

I'm solo travelers so I'm done with Ella Rock, Sri Lanka. This is my 10 perspective review (way) about Ella Rock. 1) If u coming by bus, just drop off to Ella Town. 2) If u coming by train, exit the Ella Station. 3) Check in Ella areas before or after hiking. U can get so many guesthouse, dorm, hotel, hostel in this areas. Lot of international tourists so play with the price for maked reasonable. Prepared cash because most of this accommodation can't accept card. 4) Start hiking early morning is a good choice. I'm start hiking 5.30am. 5) For facilitate climbing, walk follow the train route (from Ella Station train). That is easier way to follow the step. 6) 5-10 minutes walk after Kithalella Station, u will find a small passage to the top of the ella rock, just follow the step. 7) 45-60 minutes after climb, u will be in the top of Ella Rock. Explore the top because there have 2 or 3 top view side of the rock. 8) Don't worry if u don't bring mineral water or just finished it because there's a "tea stall" on the top. Can buy a cup tea or mineral for Rs100. 9) Wearing a properly entirely for hiking is help a lot (climbing shoes and long pant because on the way to climb there are pile of weeds). 10) Just beware some of the local people will try "helping" if u are lost by show the step/way. But in the end he will ask for the money (as guide u to the top). So if u are alone, just follow another traveller. Enjoy

Very interesting place. When you go to thisrs  place, you meet meny friendly monkeys :)))) Really nice restraurant vith falls view, good prices, nice people and enviroment. SHort way to the falls,  good place for very good pics, selfie and others :)  I give it 5  stars :)

Climbing Ella Rock was my favourite activity in Ella, it might be your favourite too. But watch out for the locals who try to "help" you with the intention of getting you lost then demanding money for guiding. You don't need a guide. Follow the railway tracks, crossing the rail bridge over the gorge. I was a bit apprehensive about this, but it's safe enough, the locals do it all the time. Shortly after crossing the bridge, locals will tell you to turn left. Don't, it's a scam to get you lost. Continue to follow the rail track past Kitalella rail station, until you are a few hundred metres past the 166.5 marker sign. The path entrance is near a rock face, GPS co-ordinates for the path entrance 6¬∞51'28.3"N 81¬∞02'39.0"E Cross over the bridge over the creek then turn left and hike up amongst the tea plantation. You will soon come to a T intersection where you will need to turn right. Follow this path and you will come to a small caf√©. The path continues up from here, if unsure the caf√© staff can generally be trusted to point you in the right direction, but it wasn't rocket science to figure out. After reaching the first lookout, the path continues along the saddle of the mountain, then you have a steep rocky section to hike up. You will then come to a wide track at the top of this, turn left and you are there. There is another cafe at the top of the mountain. Be sure to check the price before accepting anything, as the prices are as steep as the hike itself. Follow the exact same path down. Staff at the first caf√© advised of an alternative route down but this proved to be incorrect. It can get quite hot, so start early in the morning (6am-8am if possible) and bring a hat, sunscreen and at least 1 litre of water per person. The hike needs a moderate level of fitness and a fair bit of effort, but the view is amazing and well worth it.

We really enjoyed climbing this rock.It is not in that height but beautiful rock to climb and walk. Halfway we walked parallel to the railway line and explored the rock. It took a few hours but not so hard. When you visit Ella you should not miss this place.

I saw this place on the way to Ella rock because this is look tourist place. After that my Ella friend drive me to a very nice and silent Water fall which he said that is local place. You have to drive about 1hour to reach this place and you can see a lot of monkeys next to the road

We went up Ella Rock between about 8am and 12noon - this was a good time to go and we wouldn't have wanted to go any later as it was really hot in the midday sun by the time we were coming back down! We had our tour guide with us but even he asked a local for some guidance getting up and down, as the wet weather overnight had made the usual routes too treacherous for us to climb. We were taken through fields of tea and past an unnervingly steep rock face overlooking a waterfall, so it was certainly an adventure! The journey was quite steep and a lot of the time we were climbing over tree roots so I wouldn't recommend it to anyone with limited fitness or physical injuries. If you do make it up though the views are fantastic and well worth the hard trek getting up there!
Very nice hiking trip, we started at 6:00 am and it was perfect time, not to hot and not much crowded. It was very nice start for the day

You must read the reviews on the internet first about how to get there. You don‚Äôt need a guide but you will be misdirected to make it feel like you do. It‚Äôs straightforward to get there you just need to do your research. Great climb, great views and even serving tea at the top. üòÄ

Started our journey 9am and finished around 12. We walked along the tracks as other reviews stated. Found some help in taking us to the summit and the temple. Great views in between the rain showers. The views are great.  The paths to the summit vary in intensity and lengthy but are do-able for almost anyone with time and patience. Worth the trek and would recommend for the views. Guides aren‚Äôt needed providing you follow the other reviews on here. 2-300m past kithaella train station is a small path to the left from Ella and you can find your way through the forest to the top.

You should definitely visit Ella Rock! It‚Äôs more than wonderful. Also go to other viewpoints on the top (there‚Äôs more than one) Online there are some good instructions how to get there as a solo traveller, make some screenshots and you‚Äôll be fine. Btw, I didn‚Äôt have  any problem with leeches.

Here are some points you should know before you do Ella Rock. 1. It‚Äôs a steep rocky climb. Majority of the hike is fine, however when you get to the bottom of Ella Rock it‚Äôs a very steep gradient up. It lasts about 30-40mins. 2. Read an online guide to hike Ella Rock. Altas and Boots have a thorough guide including GPS map. You don‚Äôt need to hire a guide it is not that difficult. 3. If you don‚Äôt read the guide beware there are NO SIGNS. And it would be easy to get lost making you vulnerable to touts that will demand an outrageous fee. Don‚Äôt trust anyone who says they will show you the way. They will demand compensation at the end. This is a larger issue I think visitors need to be more vocal about with the Ella local council or tourism committee. Ella has thousands of tourists coming through for hiking yet there are no route markers, no signage, no free maps easily available. They are profiting from the the tourist dollar yet spending zero back on the tourist draw cards. Also this further allows touts to take advantage of lost hikers. 3. The second viewing point is nicer than the first in my opinion.  At the top you can take a loop around and I saw three different viewpoints. 4. If you can spare a few bucks buy a juice up the top.

We found this walk quite frustrating. There a number of tracks and they‚Äôre all very narrow, muddy and slippery. There‚Äôs no signs telling you where to go and the view at the top is alright but very similar to Little Adams Peak. I wouldn‚Äôt do it again.

The highlight of my trip to Sri Lanka - Beautiful Ella! I went with a local guide 'Nimbal' We left at 4am, a million stars in the sky, walked along the railway track in the dark, monks chanting echoing through the valley. The climb for me was mammoth! Nimbal was great helping me along the way. It was an incredible feeling to reach the top & see the sunrise, then experience the most beautiful view I have ever seen!  For me it was tough going up but a 'must do' climb & hey if I can do it you can too! Having said that I thought it was 6km return hike, actually 13km round trip, so proud of me :) There is also a Buddha cave, a forest walk & beautiful waterfall to climb down to see. Going down is easier in daylight tho just as amazing, reaching the base, a refreshing cup of tea & freshly made Sri Lankan breakfast in the little hut cafe, then through the tea plantations & back along the railway track. Double experience in the dark then daylight. Try for the sunrise its spectacular!

We had read about the challenging trek to Ella rock. We got down at Kithalella station. Hired a young local boy as a guide. He was a confident and chatty little fellow, who could speak some basic English speaking skills. Thanks to him, we climbed Ella rock in less than two hours, relished the views at the top and came down in another one hour

The trek is not easy to find but we find a local guy who lives in the area to show us the way and we gave him money. Because we were a lost at the beginning. The view from the top was incredible! And the trekked was not too difficult, but will pass some jungle area with long grass.

A solid hike, that requires a decent level of fitness. The walk starts along the train tracks, winding up gradually (and relatively moderately) through the tea plantations. As you near the summit the climb steepens and intensifies, with the path becoming rockier and more difficult to navigate. However, it was easier than we expected from the guidebooks we'd read - I'd say that only about the last third/quarter of the hike is challenging. I also don't think that a guide is really necessary - we easily found our way on our own based on directions from blogs (there are quite a few that set out possible routes). That being said, bear in mind that there are no route markers. Allow 3.5 to 4 hours or the hike, including time to take in the views (which are worth the walk!). An early start is highly recommended to avoid walking in the heat. We set off at 05:30, but in hindsight I would've made it at least 30 minutes earlier. For those who don't mind setting off in the dark, I also imagine that sunrise would be pretty spectacular up there.

We went with our driver to Ella Rock. We got a bit lost at first, but the walk up was amazing and very varied! Lots of rock scrambling involved and a moderate level of fitness required towards the top. The views going up were amazing!!! This is a must whilst visiting Ella!

The hike up requires mild exertion closer to the top, can be easily achieved if you have a moderate level of fitness. Go early to see the valley and avoid the fog & rain. BE WARNED - There is no signage directing you to the starting point! The directions from most locals are vague and ambiguous, they WILL send you around in circles and then offer you their services as a guide (for a fee, of course) There are MANY different paths on offer, follow your nose and keep heading UP. OUR STARTING POINT: As we faced Ella Rock at Kital Ella railway station, we turned right and walked along the train tracks for about 200m, there was an obvious track on our left. We walked down, crossed the bridge, turned right, followed the path around the tea plantation then kept heading UP. *DISCLAIMER - These are not official directions, this is the way we went and it was 100% successful. We met many other hikers following the exact same route. With these directions it can be expected to reach the top in less than 1hr. Be sure to hike in the morning as it is quite humid, if you go in the wet season you need to beat the fog & rain. Take wet weather clothing with you!

Ella rock sits about 1000m from Ella. It is best to get a guide for sunrise hike because the view will be greatly rewarded! Doing a day hike is possible because the journey is about 10km but the route is not really well paved and most of the people do get lost (and beware of locals scam along the way). Day hike could be really hot and more tiring as compare to a sunrise hike. Although equipment is not required for this hike, a fairly reasonable stamina and strength is still required because of the very rocky and steep terrain at some point. I had a sunrise hike beginning at 4am and got down to the base at about 8am (depending on the length of time you stay at the peak).

A fantastic hike - takes approximately 2.5/3  hours. Go early, because it‚Äôs cooler and watch the sun rise. We had a guide who took us along a quieter route on the way back which was great. Fabulous views but monkeys stealing food at the top so watch out! Also fences going up when we were there which will mean you have to pay entry at some point soon. It was free when we were there.

We started are trip to the waterfall and ella big rock at ella train station. This was well worth it as the walk is beautiful. Walking down the train tracks. As u come acoss the black steel bridge there is a left down towards the water full. Don't pay any locals to show u up the rock or the water full not needed. The water full is breath taking and u can climb up and down it for some better views. Then carry on up the tea fields to the top and the look out over the vast landscape as it is unreal. Spend a little time up there. The hike itself isn't hard and doesn't take too long. Enjoy

A nice morning trip! Take the shortcut through the tea fields for a steaper trip - but this I recommend do with a guide for approx 2000 rupees. I got lost in the high grass a couple of times, a local guy saved me each time, and ended up follow me all the way up. Also make sure to see the Buddha in the cave, another view point!

We went to ella after last year december it was one hell of a adventure experience. We had so many peaks to climb when i strated to climb on the 1st day i was about 71 kg and when im finishing my tour i waw abbot 62kg. That is how you utilise your vacantion. And the view from Ella rock is a awesome. And would like to visit again.

Really enjoyed this hike, although we did lose our way and had a very interesting detour on the way there. You pass the top of the waterfall on the way there, and go through some tea farms then up through the forest getting steeper until you reach the top, where you walk out onto a rocky part at the top with views on three sides (and a steep fall if you weren‚Äôt careful). Great views.

A great fun walk starting on the railway line and then climbing up. Would recommend a guide from the bottom as easy to get lost (and we also found it quashed the kids moaning ;-) ) It took us around 4 hours, maybe a little longer from our guest house. Our kids are 6 and 8 but used to walking good distances. I think it was around 10k in total with quite a reasonable climb. Great views! And a few places to buy drinks and snacks en route.

Walking on train tracks, through tea plantations, up a sheer eucalyptus forest, all with no signposting... but what a view. This is the hike to do in Ella. Take directions from your guesthouse of look out for other travellers on the route. It's tough enough to get up to the top (1.5 hours at a good pace), but the views are worth it!

Walking along the train tracks to get to the base of the 'mountain' was great fun especially if you are a fan of 'Stand by me'. The walk up was not too tough.  The views were lovely but on a really clear day would be awesome.  You'll see a really well defined dirt track when you get to the top. Don't think what my husband thought which was 'this will be a more direct route down'. It wasn't. We walked twice as long and then had to cut cross country to get to the main path (yes he was in trouble;-)). Budget for a 4 hour round trip without if you don't get lost!

You start the 3.5km trek from Kandi along the railway and then into a tea plantation before hiking up-hill, sometimes steply, until you reach the top of the Rock. The climb is well worth it.  It is extraordinary! Certainly in the top ten things to do in Sri Lanka!!! Do it as early as you can so that you miss the foot traffic and catch the weather at it‚Äôs coolest.

Hiking up to Elle rock after the first 35 min walking on the railway! a little difficult to find the right exit from the railway up to Elle rock but on internet there are many blogs that tells you where to go. NO need to take a guide!

This was a fantastic hike and my favourite while in Ella! You must get your hiking shoes on and give this one a go, it's more difficult than Little Adam's Peak if you did that and though it was difficult maybe rethink this one. It's difficult to find the start so I've attached a little MAP that may help. 1) START: Ella Railway Station. Walk the Railway South West (ask someone). Careful these are active tracks. 2) STOP once you've crossed Railway Bridge Kital Ella (first major bridge you'll cross) and on your left will be people selling food/water. Go down the stairs and check out Kithal Ella Falls with a great view of Ella and a place to cool off. (If you've arrived at Kital Ella Station (first station after where you started) you've gone to far!) 3) It gets a bit tricky from here, but your next STOP is Ella Rock "Cafe" this is at the base of the mountain, its an awesome little hut selling food, fruit and drinks. You'll have to navigate through some tea plants and there are many paths that work, just keep heading towards Ella Rock (biggest mountain). 4) From the "Cafe" head up the path in between it an the mountain (or ask someone/cafe man) and it gets difficult from here but stay on that path and head for the top! 5) Make sure you check out a few different view points while at the top, there are a few trails to follow! Be careful its a long drop! Cheers!

The hikes are really great for long exercising. It took one hour and a half for non fitness person like us. We actually took the wrong way but trying to avoid from local scammer which is quite annoying for us. Because of taking the wrong ways, we found monkeys who were eating a jackfruit hanging in a tree so the hike was quite fun and interesting for us! The views up there are stunning! Just spend enough time to enjoy all those views and don‚Äôt miss the amazing view with Ravana falls  within 10 mins walk from the top of Ella rock.

I have to admit that we walked the wrong way at first, and then got caught up in a local scam "are you lost - I can show you the way". They follow you for a while (at first you might think that they are being nice, but they will claim money for it, and can at times be rude). Turn them down straight away. Ask some locals at where you are staying on where to start the hike.The path starts on the left hand side, approximately 100meters after a trainstation (after a bridge). The path from the train tracks and all the way to the top are easy to follow, and you can`t get lost as long as you walk onto the correct path from the beginning with.If you are used to hiking this tour is not at all a problem. The view from the top is great - approx 240 degrees view over the green mountains surrounding Ella. Have a great trip! :)

We trekked up Ella rock starting at 8am just after the Ella train station. We looked up directions on a blog and found our way fairly easily. There were a couple of places you could get lost but there were a few tourists near us who we followed. The journey to the summit took us just on 1hour and 15 mins. Be careful not to follow those directing you down the wrong path or incorrect signs (use clear instructions or GPS). It is a quite steep final stretch so dress appropriately with sturdy footwear. The summit view is phenomenal. A must visit when in Ella.

We have recently returned from our holiday in Sri Lanka.  We had a wonderful guide which was organised through Walkers Tours.  We are all in our late 50s early 60s, but consider ourselves fit.  You do climb a mountain and go through a path which goes through jungle.  The views are fabulous and you see animals and birds with nature at it's best, but wear long trousers as leeches can be a problem and decent walking shoes.   A first aid kit is advisable, as my husband had a fall and a kind villager provided first aid.  However, undeterred he also made it to the top.  The reward of the views is worth the climb.

Medium difficulty hike taking around 4hrs for the round trip including rest stops. Yes you can do it without a guide if you want but we found going with a guide extremely informative and fun. He was full of interesting local knowledge and once at the top we also visited a hidden shrine and another view point which had we gone on our own we would have missed out on. Personally we thought having a guide was well worth the 2000 rupees as it added much to the overall experience. Breathtaking views at the top, rugged walking and much better than just following a path or climbing stairs (Adams peak and little Adams peak), a proper hike. This is well worth the effort. Leave Ella around 7 am (or earlier if you want to see sunrise) so that you avoid the hottest part of the day while hiking. :0)))
Confusing as expected, but eventually made it to the top. Don't worry too much because you will see a lot of people as confused as you, just enjoy the adventure!

The reviews scared me a little difficulty-wise! I‚Äôm pretty fit but don‚Äôt like rocky downhill hikes as I‚Äôve sprained my ankle so many times! We hired a guide through our guesthouse (at 2-3000 rupees for 3 of us it seemed crazy not to - why have the stress of finding the way when you can relax, enjoy the walk and contribute a little bit to a local worker at the same time?! They‚Äôre just trying to make a living like everyone else at the end of the day!) He took us in his tuk tuk to the train station where we started our hike.... left our guesthouse at 5am, hone by 8am! Watching the sunrise was so lovely. Beautiful views and wasn‚Äôt busy at the top! Yes it a bit steep at the top, you get a bit out of breath but the reviews make it sound much worse than it is! On the way down I just took it easy, no problems! Great feeling when you reach the top!

We were lucky enough to have our accom hist guide us to the top eventhough it was his day off. We did come across a guy almost to the top, doing the climb on his own, saying he was going off google maps  so i guess using a guide or not is really up to you. We went in the morning so cant comment on crowds. Takes about an hour or so to get to the top. Views are amazing. Totally worth the climb

This is a great walk and despite all of the comments about the route being hard to find, it isn‚Äôt! It‚Äôs the scammers who deliberately misinform you and lead you a complicated way in order to make you think you need to keep them as a guide. The scammers wait in a group just after the (a little scary if you‚Äôre afraid of heights) railway bridge crossing which is about 30-mins from Ella train station. They sit just above a path to the left which has a little shop selling water visible from the tracks. Even though we had downloaded a guide that said we needed to walk on for a further 10-mins on the train tracks (past the little train station called Kital Ella), we were sucked in by the very genuine lady telling us that Ella Rock was a left turn here. Which we did. We followed this path for about 10-mins through some overgrowth at times only to be caught up by a local person saying we were going the wrong way and to follow them to get to the right path. This guy looked so honest and genuine that we followed him back. He then proceeded to take us an a very complicated (& longer as we later discovered) route through the tea plantations until we came out about 25 mins from the top and hit the very obvious real path. We then had the necessary haggle about him wanting paying etc.... quite a few people were in the same boat as we carried on. On the way back, we followed the path easily and came out on the tracks exactly where we were headed for before we were misinformed about the route. On the way back on the tracks....sure enough, there was our guy - in a change of clothes - waiting for his next target alongside several others. Ella Rock was amazing and the walk was one of the best we‚Äôve done in Sri Lanka so would highly recommend but just watch out for the scam; it‚Äôs very believable!!

To reach the top of Ella Rock takes approx. 1.5 hours walking along the railway tracks then through tea plantations and paddy fields into the beautiful woods near the summit. We did it there and back in 3 hours. Its not an easy climb especially in the heat so recommend you go early to beat the sun and the crowds. The view is incredible and totally worth the sweat and a few moments of 'why'. Not alot of space at the top with people vying for the best photo spot. Top tip is there is a quieter rock/view to the left as you arrive at the top, follow the path. I think the view and pic op are much better from here. Enjoy!

I see a lot of reviews here saying not to get a guide.We got a private guide for 2500 rupees/‚Ç¨12.50.Well worth it.We didn't have to worry abt finding our way.He was knowledgeable about local wildlife. Some guides charge crazy prices and you go with a large group. If interested his name is Asanka and his phone no is 0728102142.Like many Sri Lankans he speaks in a heavy accent but he has pretty good English.

We read such intimidating things about it being really tricky and guides trying to force you into accepting their help. But in reality there is enough information online for this to now be very straightforward. Even more so if you can use gps. Or pay a couple of quid for a guide and don‚Äôt even think about it. Not a hugely taxing hike and absolutely worth it, stunning views. Start early before it gets stinking hot. We started at 7.30 and were back down by 11.30 with loads and loads of stops. If I did it again I would start at 6am though as it would also be quieter at the top

It was quite a climb! We walked from Ella town towards Kithalella station on the tracks. Then took the narrow path down hills just before the Kithalella station on the left where there was a small BO tree.(We were guided by the local postman) Once passed the bridge over the kithalella falls,we took the narrow path on the left which led us on the edge of the mountain.There,the view was breathtaking but the path was not really easy as it was covered by blady grass(spear grass). Tracking shoes or non slippery covered shoes,summer clothing,hat or cap and a bottle of water will be must-carry,as the climb needs hours and on a rough path. Be concerned not to litter or bring any polythene to the mountain as it is protected site by the forest department and also it is our mother nature! Be mindful about the trains as walking on the tracks towards kithalella. It is better to start the hike in the morning around 7am something and climb down when its noon.Evenings sometimes it rains and it is not advisable to climb up in the evening.

They way up and down are as beautiful as the sights from the peak. Quite steep in the end, but worth it! You don‚Äôt need a guide. There are good blog descriptions and enough fellow hikers you will meet on the way. But you do need good shoes with a good grip. After rain it will be quite slippery. 4 hours round trip if you take your time. Plan to be back before midday.

I saw a lot of reviews of this being easy. The guides were stopping for a lot of breaks too so it is not easy. Took us about an hour to go up and slightly less to come back down. We did not get a guide and followed a couple who had one. As there are easier ways to go up. Lovely at the top. Worth getting a big stick to help get back down as very steap near top.

It might get tricky to find the way to the top but there are lots of locals pointing you the right direction. Go early in the morning to avoid the crowds and fog, cause once the haze comes you will see nothing. The climb itself is not that hard and is very enjoyable. Just take plenty of water and suncream. If you want to prolong your trip, go to see Ravana Falls. But get to the Upper Part! They are way more beautiful and without tourists, as they are on a private land. They are not that easy to find, but it is worth the effort. At the top of Ella Rock turn left on the path. Keep the direction and walk on the ridge until you get to the Forest Monastery. The path divides into 2 or 3 directions here, turn left, slightly down from the hill. It is like you get out of the forest, go until you see a very old looking low stone wall. Turn left, down from the hill here and keep this direction. Many times you will lose the wall in the bush but keep trying and you will find it again. Open street maps will help you a lot, the path is marked there and I think MAPS.ME shows the way as well. After 20 mins it gets you to a road, there is a sign and a locked gate to the private land here. On the sign there are several numbers ( 077 531 2276 is one of them). Call and someone will come shortly to open the gate for you. After paying 500 Rupies you will be taken for a tour. The waterfall from here is magnificent and you will get a private bath in the natural pool right under the waterfall. You can stay as long as you like, just be aware of leeches, they really suck! More info here https://www.tripadvisor.com/Hotel_Review-g616035-d4677705-Reviews-Ravana_s_Secret-Ella_Uva_Province.html
Look,it‚Äôs not easy to navigate there if you are the first people trying to catch a sunrise.You can get pretty lost but you will eventually get there and the view is great

Last month we visited the ella rock . I could not describe the beautiful view of that site. Its amazing and I thanks a lot for our guide of radient tours . We had a good tea and stayed there more than one hour... Thank you John S

I hiked along the railway tracks from Ella Station, passing the sign "prohibited to walk on the railway line", but even the stationmaster told me to go this way. Keeping a lookout for trains it took me less than an hour to reach the path on the left that led me through fields where farmers were bust attending their crops. The path had a few branches and i found myself backtracking a couple of times after taking the wrong turning. However there were plenty of people coming down the path who put me in the correct direction. There are two quite steep sections before i reached the top. Fortunately it was about 10.30 am and the skies were clear offering a terrific view. There were two enterprising locals selling lemon tea and bottled water at the top, triple price here, but who is complaining as the lemon tea was really good. I guess by the time i returned to Ella Station the hike had taken e the best part of four hours, but this is a hike one should not miss.

If you are really an energetic soul, you can climb up easily any time during day time. In a normal pace it'll take around 4hrs max and you can reduce that to 2.5-3hrs with around 30mins stay at the summit with moderate pace. Trail just below from the KITHALELLA railway station will be much easier. Enjoy the views up there....!!

We  climbed this amazing rock it is not the easiest climb and certainly in the heat it can be quite exhausting ,so going as early in the morning as possible is the best thing to do there are guides who will help you up they charge a fee this is something you should agree before the climb ; take lots of water
One reason to go to Ella. Climb over the rocks, have a swim in the pool near the road, but be careful as the water can gush after heavy rain

Make sure you get to the actual Ella Rock summit. There is a Buddha there,  as customary. The rock where everyone stops is just 100m from the real place. The climb was a little tough but we enjoyed it!  Recommend!!

We got a guide and tuk tuk from our hotel. Our guide took us the ‚Äòshort cut‚Äô past the top of the waterfall and through a tea plantation before the steep climb to the summit. The view from the top was spectacular. It was misty but the weather changes so quickly up there that there was a few clear moments for us to take some photographs and enjoy the view. I would suggest that this is for people of good fitness as it is quite a difficult climb and very steep on the way down and can put pressure on your joints.

We usually don't hire guides but the man running our guest house has been in business for many decades. When we started out along the tracks, there were many tourists walking the same way. I thought I may have overpaid to have just been able to follow the herd. Our guide then took us through farm land and over to a different point with a huge overlook and no tourists. After we made our way over to "Ella Rock" where there were 50-60 other tourists. The hike down from this point was brutal. I was very happy at seeing the exhusted faces of hikers that we paid to take the easy route up!
Very enjoyable walk along the train tracks, little tea plantation..it‚Äôs not a very obvious path up top, make sure you get the directions before you go.

Having completed Adams Peak the day before we decided to hike Ella Rock. A completely different experience, a tougher climb and a completely different terrain therefore well worth doing them both. We stated from Ella Centre, joining the train track and following it for about 20 minutes before finding the left turn for Ella Falls. You cross a short footbridge across the falls and the path forks two ways, we followed other travellers guidance and took the left fork. It is a little confusing at first with no definite path and long grass but it seems all trails lead in the same direction. Do watch out for some of the locals though trying to confuse matters. Follow your instinct and other travellers and you soon reach the first vista. From here you pass through trees and begin your climb to the top. We walked moderately and it took about 2hours. The views from the summit are awesome and you soon forget the strenuous climb. We took a completely different route down but again, arrived back at the bridge. No need at all for a guide and a great way to spend a morning. Good footwear is a must and there are some places at the start selling refreshments and even a man making tea at the summit!

Exhausting hike. If you're short on time better to hike mini Adam 's peak instead of this. There are two routes. One is to hike, which is the shorter yet more exhausting route. The other is a walking path which takes longer time but you can enjoy it.

Beautiful views after a great trek! Definitely worth it and highly recommended. Very quiet when we were up there (about 2pm). We found it easily with the help of directions from some reviews and websites. The hottest part was walking along the train track, once the ascent started, a lot of it was shaded over by trees which was very welcomed!
A drop down to the falls through a lovely hotel and you arrive at a viewpoint area. A bit of a climb with steps and steep road but worth the effort. Refreshments bar at the bottom and at the hotel!
The view is simply amazing! The way there is quite an experience as well. No need for a guide if you prepare yourself: a lot of websites propose step by step walkthrough to get there!

You definitely need to look up the instructions for the first part of the walk - maps.me app has a great set of instructions which we followed. There were plenty of people that gave up because they couldn't find the route. Some people paid for local guides to help them. But if you know where you're going, then you will be treated to an awesome walk and finally a brilliant view. The walk is relatively easy but I recommend proper shoes instead of flip flops as it's quite steep towards the end.

Takes just under two hours up and an hour and a half down at average walk pace. Slightly tricky path directions wise but usually you can ask other tourists on the way. Good mix of trainline, tea plantation and hill climbs. Amazing views from the top. Some locals will try to help you along the way for a small fee, not always necessary but if you keep getting lost it's probably worth it.

If you have managed to convince yourself the blog you read gave good enough directions and you are looking at this as your final check, it's totally worth it. First off, be at the train station no later than 8 am. (You will thank me when you are descending during the humidty spike of the late morning) From there you walk about 45 minutes to an hour to the "base" of the mountain. You can expect to take anywhere from 1 hour to 2 hours to climb depending how long you stop and marvel at nature's beauty. ( The journey to the top is filled will beautiful things. Trees, flowers, tea fields, and a half way view point. Make sure you enjoy the way up as well as the top) When you make it to the top stop and enjoy the view from the rock itself but don't stop there. When you pass the small cabin at the top walk in from of it and continue on the small path that takes you to the second viewpoint. You will walk throught a beautiful stand of trees. When you reach the tree that looks like a natural hammock. That is the second viewpoint. We spent about an hour there without seeing anyone else. The main rock is very crowded. Although we have had no problems finding help while travelling in Sri Lanka, many of the locals were pointing other people in the wrong direction. Making many people confused and frustrated. Do your homework and be confident in your route. Going at it blind will only discourage you. Please enjoy and respect the beauty of nature.

From the train station, it will take you about 1h30-2h to reach the summit, and 1h to get back. You will probably stop many times to take some pictures. The way to go there was less difficult than expected (lot of people take a wrong way). From the staion, the easiest way is to take left and follow the rails toward Kital Ella (yes, just walk on the train tracks). Then , pass the km post "166 1/2" and 2 min later you will take a path left (just after some rocks on the left). You will arrive immediately at a small bridge. Pass the bridge and take left at the fork. Then follow the main path, you can't get lost. If a local wants to be your guide, decide the price before, otherwise you can be sure he will try to get extra money (we saw a group of 5 people arguing with their guide after the walk. He demanded 1500LKR from each of them...) Good luck and enjoy!

We climbed during the day on a cooler day (we'd done pidurangala at sunrise and the sunrise view from our guesthouse was enough for us) and so the haze/mist didnt make for the best photos but was pretty special and you're only surrounded by 30 or so tourists rather than the 100s we were told about at Little Adams. we didnt have a guide - i used the nomadic boys blog and directions from our hotel - we were up in just over and hour and a half and was a great walk past the small holdings on the railway, the school children and the small paddy fields and local washing pools. the steep bit is tricky on rough ground and dodging other climbers but is only 20 minutes or so.
we travelled with Nature Exploration and Conservation Society members. They guided us well.we enjoyed and satisfied with their surport to us.Early morning hike was good and easy for us.
Great view from the top! U can watch right down on Little Adams Peak. Walk from Ella trainstation and experience walking on the railroad!

We set off at 4.30 am from our hotel and went with a guide for 2,500 rupees total for the two of us. It was a hard and quite difficult walk and took us 1.5 hours to get up (we are both fairly fit and in our 20s) and we wore good trainers, our guide wore his flip flops and was steaming ahead! The view at the top was worth it though and then it just took 1 hour to walk down back to Ella. I would definitely recommend if you don't mind a slight challenge. If it was wet though I could imagine it being really slippy. I would definitely recommend a guide if you go at night. We organised ours through the hotel.
They try to get lost you by telling you wrong direction, and their accomplices are helping you find right way, but they ask for money of course.

Great hike up to the top. There is lots of things to see on the way up and it is a beautiful setting. Follow some good instructions and you should have no issues finding the top. Or just follow other people as lots do the trail.

We started at 6am and walk through the railway. you need to go after the kathilella station hardly left. we didn't take a guide, we found a good description with pictures in a blog. So it was easy to find and at least I become a guide for lost fellows. the Hikking is advanced but not impossible. with enough breaks everybody can do this. we hardly recommended very good boots. The climb is rocky, slippery and steep. So do not risk anything. at the midtime it start very heavy to climb so don't lose time. we recommend to go to the "temple", then your up. most haven't recognize it. it us st least behind the small house the road right and needs 10min foot walk. it is a better view in my opinion. I will not said it is a must have to climb the rock, but then you have the time do it!
Nice walk and a great view. A little steep going up, but all right - even for a couple in the late sixties.

Many route descriptions available in the net. Do not worry, even if a wrong path taken all of them lead to the peak. And you will not be alone as this is very frequently visited track. Very scenic and giving possibility to touch the countryside
Beautiful hike up the hill through tea plantations. The second and last part is a bit steep, so wear proper shoes!

We took the railway tracks and across the waterfall to Ella Rock.Got lost and was helped by a local to find our way through the villages and tracks that can take you round in circles.We found the simple way on the way back which was much easier than the way we Came.Not for people with mobility issues as the last 20 mins is uphill on rocky,tree rooted tracks.Hard slog for the over 50s which is us.Well Worth the stunning views at the top

Ella Rock is a decent hike, 2 hours up, 2 hours down, with no scrambling required but good hiking footwear is a must. The view from the top is great, although we caution you from trusting locals' directions too much, as we saw some people being given wrong information intentionally (so a guide can "save" you, possibly). There is a cafe at the base of the mountain as well as people selling drinks at the top (make sure to stay hydrated as there is a lot of exposure to sun, especially during her approach).

I regard this as the highlight of my 5 days in Ella. It's a little tricky to find the right trail. I did this a few months ago now so the memory is not as fresh for my exact trail but I find the tour on a blog online which laid it out perfectly. Someone posted a map in the photos that is really useful as well so recommend doing a little research in advance. The main point is on the rail tracks look for 166 1/2 mile marker, on left, keep walking until you see Yellow 15kmh sign and right behind it although slightly obscured by long grass is a 166 1/4 sign, this is where you turn off. I'll include pics of it below.  You cross a bridge and head on up. it seems the locals purposefully keep it tricky to find so tourists will hire a local guide to bring them up. I set out quite early just after 6am. My hostel is right on the train tracks so just matter of walking until the turn off. Clouds tend to come in after the morning but luckily for me the views were perfect. It took about 90 minutes to reach the top from my hostel. As I went early I had it to myself, the views are sensational and much better than Little Adam's peak imo. It can be pretty hot in Ella and with the clouds I'd really recommend setting the alarm and starting early. I promise you it is worth it.

Really enjoyed our 4 hour walk up the rock, we chose the difficult route amd found it trying but certainly within the abilities of most people (I'm 64 and claim the title of Oldest Englishman to have made the difficult ascent) It is possible to wander off track and take longer but I imagine if you're walking uphill youll get there sooner or later. The views from the top are worth the climb. Enjoy!

Differently from all the reviews here we went there today and it‚Äôs not confusing at all! Actually if you follow the instructions is pretty easy to find your way, you don‚Äôt need guide or any help! The way up from the middle point is very taught, but If you don‚Äôt want to go all the way up the middle view is awesome!

Take a tuktuk to the next station after Ella (or walk the tracks) from there it is 100 mtrs to the trailhead turning off sharply to the left from the tracKs. You very soon  cross the little river on a bridge and thereafter immediately turn LEFT upwards (on the bridge is painted a sign indicating you have to turn right, this is a scan...) From there staight ahead through tall grass and bushes, until you meet a small cafe, and then join the others walking up. Cant miss it. You dont need a guide!!

Ella rock roughly takes you 1.5 hours to climb. If you're fit and healthy it can be climbed in a shorter time. It really is a beautiful hike, taking you through long grass, bridges, beautiful forests. There are many routes to hike, and you can get guides who will take you as well. The views once you reach the top are excellent. Definitely a must do when you reach Ella!

It's a quite path.Not much hard to climb.At the end you will end up with beautiful view.Can see the place where that "Ravana Falls"started.No need of guide you can find the path easy. There was shop to buy some snacks and drink king coconut.

The path was hard to find even though we googled it before we went there. We found a local with tons of tobacco in his mouth which helped us to the top. He told us that many people get lost and we would too if it wasn't for him.
