We were a bit nervous about doing this walk as we‚Äôd read many places online that it was very confusing, with locals trying to lead you the wrong way in order to make a few rupees getting you back on track and even going as far as to make fake signs and growing tall grasses over the tracks to confuse tourists ‚Äî from our personal experience, this sounds very much like extremely colorful, exaggerated myths. Firstly, our basic offline map as well as Google Maps could clearly show us all the possible pathways which we could take. Secondly, the many locals we met kindly and accurately pointed us in the right direction on several occasions when the pathways lead us through their property. We had zero problems with navigation, and this was one of the things which made this a beautiful, albeit in parts tough, walk. The views of Ella and the surrounding hills/mountains, like Little Adam‚Äôs Peak, were all worth the treck. The province in general is gorgeous. We came down feeling great, and I also really enjoyed the little walk down the train tracks to reach the entrance of the route.

Went up on our second day and just enjoyed it. We decided to take the steeper and quicker way, which at the end got quite exhausting as we rushed up there. The two viewing spots are just amazing and totally worth the effort. Good workout with a lovely finish.

Go early! The walk along the train tracks is stunning as is a somewhat gruelling climb at the end. Make sure you go past both Ella and Kital Ella railway stations before turning on to the path. Do this!

We took our kids (7&9) hiking up Ella Rock, they both loved it & enjoyed a cool drink on the way back down! Fun walking along the railway tracks & then the climb. Our 7 year old had tired legs at the end but he did it! I would suggest wearing decent footwear & heading off early. We started at 7.15am. We organised a guide which was worthwhile for us with the kids.
It‚Äôs quite tricky to find the path , look for foreigners and follow them. Don‚Äôt trust the locals who will point you in the wrong direction (as what others on trip advisors have mentioned)

As many others have said dont get sucked in by the scamming locals. Unfortunately we went before reading the reviews here and fell into the trap! The trail seems to be designed to confuse tourists but all roads seem to lead to the top. The walk itself is fairly easy going and the views on the way are breathtaking.

Ella rock is a beat place to visit. Not that much hard to hike. Can go with family. But it took about 3 hours to complete the hike. Stunning views are there. If your are going to Ella Rock by train (From Colombo), get down in Kithal Ella Station. The station before Ella railway station. A small station. Less facilities. But nearest station to the starting point of the Ella Hike. If you get down in Ella Station you have to walk again about 2 Kms to opposite direction.

A definite must do. It took us 4 hours there and back from our central Ella hotel. That included plenty of stops and a 15 minute rest at the summit. For those nervous of doing it, my wife has a bad knee and coped ok. A 90 minute comfortable walk gets you to the final challenging climb so walk there, take in the view and decide how you‚Äôre feeling! The route we took was per the advice  below. Along the train tracks from Ella station, Beyond the metal bridge, past the station and about 300 meters past the 166.5 sign, a sharp left at the granite rock. The rock is obvious - so keep going on the railway if you are unsure. It‚Äôs highly unlikely you‚Äôve missed it. Very soon after turning Left you‚Äôll see a small bridge over pretty rapids so that‚Äôs your confirmation you took the right turn. After  that follow your nose through the tea plantation and up to the base of the climb. This takes 30 mins ish. We made a couple of wrong turns but the terrain is ok so a couple of mistakes does you no harm. If you go the wood route - look out for the monkeys chilling from the heat. Contrary to other accounts on here we found the locals helpful in pointing us the right way. If in Doubt, buy a drink from one of the huts and ask your seller the way to go - he has less motive to lead you astray! Also - there was an annoying seller near the summit sounding a regular horn - if in doubt follow the noise! Final 20 min summit is comfortable if you‚Äôre reasonably fit and injury free. Even if you‚Äôre neither of those, there is no rush and plenty of spaces to catch your breath. We walked 10-2 which I‚Äôd suggest is the latest for the morning stint as the heat kicked in on the route back. Enjoy. We loved it.

I really enjoyed the walk to and from Ella rock. But they don‚Äôt put up any signs there (so that you will hire a guide), so it can be a bit confusing. And old farmer sent me in the wrong direction just so he could charge me some rupees for guiding me back to the track. View from the top is also great and it‚Äôs not too hard getting up there.

We walked from Ella to the top and back. Single way takes about 2 hours at a normal pace. First you walk about 45 minutes along the train track to Kithalella. There, the way to the top begins. There are no hiking trails on Google maps, but you can use the app maps.me for an offline map. With the app, it's a piece of cake. Once at the top, use maps.me for other view points, like the one with the rawanna falls. The other viewpoints were less crowded when we were there. The views are amazing.

We hiked up Ella Rock at 5 am to catch the sun rise but unfortunately it was a cloudy morning. Having said that as soon at the sun was up and out, the views were indescribable. It‚Äôs a beautiful place and you get great views of little Adams peak. However, even though you do not have to pay to get to the top, We did notice that a ticket office was being built with a fence 30 meter back from the edge. Soon to start charging people.

I hiked in from the railroad tracks. There are several approaches from town, just ask. I went mid-day, so I was able to follow others for the most part (mostly coming down), I got lost a few times, but someone was always there to point the way.There are some amazing views, and a few places to pick up snacks and drinks once you leave the tracks-- the Ella Rock Cafe(?) made fresh mango juice, and let me choose the mangoes from a tray! (it looks like they were constructing a rest stop at the top, which might be running in a few months). Afterwards, take the extra 10 minutes (left if you are walking back from the jutting rocks) to hike t0 a second viewpoint, just near an impromptu temple, with a couple of Buddha statues and such

Not sure why the guidebook Lonely Planet encourages walkers to hire a guide, it really isn't necessary if you research online the best way to go. There are plenty people walking up Ella's Rock too to know you're going the right way. There are forks in the path and yes the waymarkers have become faided or hidden but it's quite simple. Ignore the locals suggesting which way to go as they seem to want to put tourists off scent (probably so you'll get lost and need a guide) walk fairly easy with sharp inclined at the top. And a rewarding view at the summit.

My accommodation host acted as a guide here and he showed us one way up and a different way down . We avoided the crowds by going up via the waterfall direction ( many use google map but local knowledge is also useful ! ) . And came down by going to the summit and at the bottom caught a bus back into Ella . In total about 17000 steps . The highlights are the great views , walking along the railway line , and the adventure and sweat exerted to climb up and also its tricky going down . You will get some brilliant pictures . Take Water and good solid boots or trainers . There are coconuts for sale and water .

Some quick google research to get good directions and this will set you up for a foolproof hike up to the top of the hill. The only super important instruction is finding the left hand side turn off (almost a full u-turn) of the railroad about 5min after you pass Kithalella station. We left Ella train station at around 7.30am and this was perfect. We avoided the mid day heat while doing the tough uphill climb to the top, and when we arrived we had the summit (~9am) to ourselves for around 5-10mins before the crowds started to form. There was a lovely local selling milky tea at the top for ~R150. The view is spectacular from the summit and we loved relaxing at the top and enjoying the sights. We got to witness a train going through Ella, a soaring eagle and were lucky enough to not have any cloud cover to speak of. It‚Äôs definitely a good physical challenge but worth it. On our way down, the trail was properly busy and I can imagine that from about 10am it‚Äôd be a bit more crowded at the top.

Really enjoyed our climb. The view from the top and walk along the railway line was unforgettable. You definitely need proper shoes but if you‚Äôre vaguely fit and ok with the heat, you will manage it with no real problem. You don‚Äôt need a guide. There are loads of useful blogs online. We found the Atlas and Boots blog particularly useful.

Loved this hike!! It took about 3-4 hours round trip.  The first 40 is just walking along the railway tracks (beware of 'guides' telling you you're going the wrong way).  We found great directions online beforehand with pictures and helpful descriptions.   The last 20 minutes or so is STRAIGHT UPHILL.  Bring water, but it looks like they might be building a cafe or something at the top.  Would highly recommend for any traveller to Ella!

This hike took us about 3hrs from town- return. The views were spectacular, my only advice is make sure you know where to go if your not using a guide. Unfortunately so of the locals will try trick you into going the wrong way.
Quite a tough walk and we seriously recommend using a local guide.  The second half of the walk is steep, rocky and a bit slippery so you need decent shoes.  The views at the top are stupendous.

Best going in the morning because of the weather. Better start early morning and the scenery with the sun rise is very nice. It's not too hard, but you will definitely be sweating and taking breaks on the way up.

I had read a lot of reviews about Ella‚Äôs rock, people trying to rip you off, needing a tour guide, people sending you in the wrong direction, how ‚Äòthe locals‚Äô keep the vegetation high to confuse you..... I must say, I don‚Äôt agree with any of those sentiments! With some slight trepidation, we set off relatively early, 7.30/8am and made our way down the tracks. Having read numerous reviews I was half expecting to be ambushed by ‚ÄòThe locals‚Äô en route to the top.... all we saw was a few people trying to make a bit of extra money off a captive audience. We walked down the tracks until the turning just after Kittal Ella and turned off the path which started to lead us over the bridge and into the mountains. We didn‚Äôt see anyone trying to tell us we were going the wrong way or trying to enforce their navigation skills on us, but that‚Äôs just our experience. I would say wear appropriate footwear, my wife wore some with minimal grip and you really do need grip to get to the top, but more to get back down! There are two routes, as everyone mentions and we plucked for the shorter; more direct route. When we reached the summit there was a couple of people there, however, by the time we walked down at 11am, there were scores of people making the trip up - highlighting the need, or lack thereof, of a guide. That being said, if you want one, that‚Äôs cool, we went wrong a little, but got back on track pretty quickly. On the route back down we stopped off for a coconut at the shack and took in some of the views and then went for some lunch. It is a lovely experience but at times can get a little tough, especially the parts that are wet! Very enjoyable!

If, like me, you're adverse to steep, uphill, seemingly endless climbs, then, like me, you will by no means relish this experience. It's all more or less endurable until the very last part that just killed me. Having said that, my friend - the avid trekker - literally ran up it. Show off (*queue scowl*). There are two routes to the top, both follow the railway track for a time, then at a certain point there's a sign for 'Ella Rock' and your map may agree - don't take this way. It's much longer and way easier to go downhill than up. Instead, just carry on a little while longer along the track, then there's some faded blue paint on a rock to the left - go down here instead. Then you just follow the path along and up and eventually you'll get there. I'd recommend going back the first way when you leave though, it is a bit more of an obscure path, but it's pretty and you go past a nice waterfall. To go that way, you just turn off right when you reach the little hut with the very expensive water and snacks again, instead of going straight, down the way you came. The actual view from Ella Rock is nice, over the mountains and everything. ...I'm not gunna lie, it didn't completely blow my mind, (I was pretty mad about the climb... and we forgot snacks) but it was really nice, I'm just being a Grinch. We sat up there for a fair while just chilling and chatting, it was all very enjoyable.

The hike to Ella Rock is a really nice hike - do some research for directions (definitely best to walk along the rail tracks), it is a bit strenuous going up, but well worth the effort.  Morning is best when the sky tends to be bluer and the weather is cooler.  They are constructing a fence and the area continues to get more popular so hike up now when you can still access the rock.

It was a nice hike to the top. We decided to just follow open street map and ended up by climbing super steep stairs and walking through very thick terrain. I recommend the path that goes from the train track. The view from the top is spectacular!

We went to Ella Rock today. As there was a very good description how to get there in the travel guide of Stefan Loose we felt safe to do it without guide. The start was very easy to find and we hiked along the railways as described. After a black bridge on the railways from which you can see the waterfalls, a group of local people stood around and sent us left. We were kind of confused as the travel guide only mentions to go left after mile 166.5 (train signals) but followed the local advice. The path looks similar to the further description in our travel guide but we ended up nowhere in a tea plantation where out of a sudden a friendly tea lady offered her help to find the way. We followed her through pathes you can‚Äôt really call so - nothing tourists would ever find - and as she also seemed to lead us back and forth, sometimes stopping to get more money, we really felt ripped off after a time. Fortunately we saw a group of tourists on the other site of a tea plantation we crossed with her and so could left the tea lady (who still insist her way would be the right one) and found the main trail again. When coming down the whole correct track, we saw that the locals just sent us left about 600m to early and met other tourists who had the same experience. We crossed those locals on the way back and asked them what the intention was. They just said ‚Äûthere are two ways‚Äú...and when we told another arriving tourist group to not follow their instructions but go 600 m further to meet the main track they got really angry. We anyway told everyone we met on the way back to not go the wrong way - so I guess their business was over at least for today. Besides this experience the trail is very nice and the views are worth the steep hike. Enjoy!!

It's a journey along the railway track, therefore if families with kids are planning to go then please take extra care when walking along the track. At the very point where you are exiting the track there'll be people offering their help in return for money. I strongly advice to not to take help from any of those people. The journey to the top is a little bit of a hard climb, therefore I advise all of you to wear appropriate footwear and clothes. If possible take a bottle of water and a camera of course. On your way up you'll meet certain shops offering King coconut drinks but I strongly advise you'll not to buy them from those shops as they're double the price. And when on the top, please DONOT go to the very edge as it's very slippery. If the weather is not good, then please I strongly won't recommend this climb as it can be highly dangerous when raining. And for those families with small kids who decide to take help from those guides you meet along the way, they'll try to take you to the very edge of a waterfall to click some photos on your way up, Please DONOT go with them to the edge and please REFUSE their request, I'm telling this as I noted that during my climb. Most of the people will come to you'll and will tell you that you'll are headed in the wrong direction and pretend to give a help to you'll but please refuse them and follow other people who are headed up. For your information there are 16 different roads to the top :-) , yeah so don't think about it now. Once you get to the top enjoy the view & click some photos, I recommend you go for the climb early in the morning at 7.45AM in the morning so that the view will be perfect.

There are decent instructions in the internet on how to go there. If you are too lazy, get a guide, shouldn't be too expensive. If you are adventurous, go and figure out your way withother hikers. The last half of the hike is hard for normal people. Seriously. Wear proper shoes. Difficulty: HARD Total time: 6 hours (up and down) on casual speed
Ella is an interesting spot. You need to take time to sit in cafes or sit and watch the falls.This is one of the best falls.

I planed to go Ella Rock, however, when we were walking towards, a Sri Lankan came and said we were walking in a wrong path, and pretended to show us the right one. absolutely amazing trekking, starting the trek through rail road and vegetation and village.  we started late in the afternoon, didn't had time to explore full.

We walked the rock unguided. Walking along the train line, go past the waterfall, past the Kithal Ella railway station in about 5 min you will see SMALL red writing on a rock to the left of the track just before a path. Take this path, cross the bridge, walk through high vegetation, once you see a little shop, follow the path to its right and it will take you to the top. The first view point was amazing and not too difficult to get to. The second part of the hike was DIFFICULT to say the least. I believe I am reasonably fit and it was tough.

I think you'd need to go with a guide, would be difficult to do it without one. It was a cloudy day, but still enjoyed it. My partner and I are in ok shape, so I thought the hike wasn't too bad. We were up and down in 2.5hrs.

The first half to 2/3 of the hike isn't too bad. The last 20 to 30 minutes is pretty steep and tough, but the views at the top are worth it. It is pretty easy to get lost prior to the midway lookout point. We got turned around and a local farmer got us back on track for a couple hundred rupees.

I did the Ella Rock treck and found it absolutely amazing and it only made me fall even more in love with Sri Lanka. Like Sri Lanka itself the treck is very diverse in terms of the trails you go through. First you walk on the railway track followed by tea plantation and then the higher you get you are taken through the pine forrest. About half way there is a small tea stall where you can enjoy tea, fresh coconuts, soft drinks, water, rotis. I recommend to start out early in the morning as it becomes too hot once you reach midday. But that is a personal preference.

we got up early and left for our hike to ella rock just after 6am. we read that it's not very obvious the path to get up there and that was very much true. I think they intentionally don't have a clear path so you hire a guide. we followed the train track out of ella and then made our way to the top. it was tough and through a lot of bush but most definitely with the view. the way we went down was totally different to the way we went up and that was not intended! it took around four hours all together.

Guys, just find a good guide before you go. I know that you can do it on your own but a good local guide can make you be hosted by local families and try their food, as I did. Also we took off the route track that turned to be really fun. In overall, the place is great.

When walking along the railway lines, ignore people telling you to turn left at the waterfall (they‚Äôve even made a fake sign). You can go this way, but it‚Äôs very easy to get lost. We climbed Ella rock yesterday and it was totally worth it. Find map and direction on Google as some locals will send you to wrong direction. Also try to go as soon as you can. Absolutely beautiful view from the top, a nice trek through tea plantations and jungle to get there as well!

We did the little trek up to the top. There was beautiful views aplenty and it was only a tad strenuous the last 300 mtrs (but we also had to carry the two-year old. I'd recommend bringing a toddler carrier to the last bit of the trek.

Try and avoid anyone offering help with trail. You do not need it.  Just go online and google Hiking Ella Rock...several videos maps etc...very pleasant walk even if it is obscured by clouds. Causal 4 hours, but can be done in 2 1/2 if you move.

There's no any signs or Map.some said need a Guide for get the direction.But that is not true.villagers will help to you. for rainy days it's very slippery. Top of the mountain Restaurant and food chargers not so good. very expensive.

Is a short trek uphill, work really nice views on the way, there is lots of tourist everywhere but watch it! Done locals will try to take you far from the road and then charge you to take you back, a guide is NOT necessary. If you have to ask, ask to the people working at the farms or other tourist, locals just waiting are a tourist trap!

Ella Rock wasnt easy to reach and we got lost, but we made it eventually, its a bit hard of a hike, but dont go back if youre tired, take a break and continue, i promise you the View on the Top Is Worth it !

We followed the route plan from gapyearescape.com ‚ÄòElla rock hike‚Äô pretty easy to find and yes like people have said ignore the locals they sit at s place bit before and tell you to go a certain way then for you to get lots and need there help (for a few I believe) anyways follow the instruticons it‚Äôs pretty easy going mostly until the end where there‚Äôs about 20 minutes of steep walking but worth it in the end

We started our trek in early morning i.e. around 04:30. In fact it was dark only at that time. We started our trail along the track. I were group of 4 guys. We stopped at multiple places to take some snaps. We got lost in between and had to hire local guide. There are two path, one had  vertical climb and other one is long but has gradual slope. We opted for the vertical climb and reached the mountain peak in 2 hours. The view from top was breath taking. One can see the Ella Gap and the Ella town from the top. We stayed around for 20-25 mins. Cool breeze made our climb a bit easy. There was also a group of locals who had done night camping. Post that, Guide took us to the other side of the peak which comes under national park. One can see statue of Lord Buddha. On return we opted for the easier path. We visited the waterfall where some locals were enjoying their bath. We came back to Ella town around 10 AM. Level - Hard (provided you take the difficult route) Time - 4 hours (includes taking pictures, time spent on top, waterfall) Preparation - Start the climb at 4:00 - 5:00 Wear proper trekking shoes and plenty of water as you won't get anything in route.

Ella rock is a good hike with a strenuous vertical climb towards the end. If it was raining I would imagine that particular part would be extremely slippy due to the muddy clay so think about this if it is raining. The views are wonderful but in all honesty the views from little Adams peak are much more spectacular with a lot less effort. It can be confusing to find the correct route as locals like to trick you into thinking you're not going the right way in order to play guide. You really don't need a guide if you follow a few of these pointers. Ignore the locals next to the signs stating the way to Ella falls and rock near the train station. Keep walking on the tracks until between post 166 1/2 and 166 1/4 There will be some boulders/rock face on your left with remnants of blue paint which originally had a sign for Ella rock. At the rock there is a sharp left turn and walk across the bridge where there is a slyly hidden left turn (we missed it) to take to follow the route which is straight forward from there.

This is a must do if you are in ella, get up early as its hard work and doing it in the mid day sun would be hellish. If you get lost just get one of the guides people say dont but they only want a few ¬£ and i assure you its better than being lost there. View at the top is amazing

Pros: - Google for a ‚Äòhow to hike ella rock‚Äô for a detailed guide (unable to post external links) - Download the map into offline maps on Google Maps. The navigation waypoints on one of the top results are spot on (the blogs do not offer services) - Great Views - Leave early e.g 6:00/7:00am to avoid the heat. Cons: - Only listen to advice from mothers, children and workers, there are locals looking to misguide you in order to subsequently hire them as a guide. - Leave early to avoid the midday Sun

If you're in Ella this is a must. It's more challenging than little Adam's Peak but offers a much greater reward at the end. I really recommend this trek when you are in Ella. The view is really beautiful from the top. We need 2 hours for Go up and town.

It is not a hard one, it takes only a couple of hours but you will get a marvellous view. Also, keep in mind there are two view points on the top. Regarding the path, we went with a guide and it we think it is necessary.

With a good gps and a gps trace you can do the hike by yourself. If you do so, ignore the local people telling you that you are going to die falling off the cliff. Lovely 4 hour return trip, it's an easy climb until the last bit but it's all worth it for the views

We walked from the Village View Homestay (the best accommodation) and walked along the track and then up the side of Ella Rock to reach the peak. We left at around 4:15 and caught sunrise but would leave about 3:45 next time just so you can enjoy the walk and get there in plenty of time. So some locals have left misleading signs and directions so you get lost and have to be guided but we were given some great instructions by our Homestay host. You really don‚Äôt need a guide just stick to the directions. I‚Äôve attached an image of a map given to us which was pretty accurate. Walk along the track (Kandy direction) stay on the track until you pass Kithul Ella station (I think it‚Äôs called). Once you are between the rail markers 166 1/2 and 166 1/4 you turn off the track to your left almost back on yourself. Walk down this track approx 100m then you‚Äôll cross a bridge over a small stream/waterfall and you‚Äôll come to a tea plantation. Take the left fork and continue along this path. Keep going and don‚Äôt stop. There will be lots of turnings off but you just have to stay on track. Eventually you‚Äôll get to the end of the tea plantation and come to an abundance of eucalyptus trees. The paths then split. We took the left track which gets daily steep and difficult at times especially the last 20/30 Minutes we were pretty out of breath but it‚Äôs a direct route to the top. To be honest as soon as you reach the eucalyptus trees I think you can take any route up as long as you‚Äôre on a path that‚Äôs heading up. We came down via a different route which joined up with our initial path amongst the trees which was an easier descent. The whole trip from the Village Biew Homestay was 7 miles and on the way up took us 1 hour and 18 Minutes. We were racing to get up there for the sunrise though. Worth it. Once at the top you get an incredible view of the valley below and the sun coming up behind little Adams peak.

A rewarding hike with views over the valley and Ella below. We set off at 8:30 am and although it wasn't really hot I would recommend an hour earlier for a more pleasant temperature. The upper slopes are covered in gum trees and actually feels alot like Australia.
